4. File Upload & Download

Goal: Handle multipart uploads and streaming downloads.

python
import os
from flask import send_from_directory

UPLOAD_FOLDER = "uploads"
os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)
app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"] = UPLOAD_FOLDER

@app.route("/upload", methods=["POST"])
def upload_file():
    file = request.files["file"]
    file.save(os.path.join(app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"], file.filename))
    return {"status": "uploaded"}

@app.route("/files/<filename>")
def get_file(filename):
    return send_from_directory(app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"], filename)

📍 Stage 1 — Core Concept: Flask Is Minimal

Flask is a microframework — it gives you:

  • Routing (@app.route)

  • Request/response handling

  • Template rendering (Jinja2)

  • Static file serving

  • Extensibility (plugins for DB, auth, etc.)

It doesn’t force structure or include ORM/auth by default.

Code: Hello World

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask

# Create the app
app = Flask(__name__)

# Define a route
@app.route("/")
def home():
    return "Hello, Flask!"

# Run app
if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

Run:

bash
python app.py

Visit: http://127.0.0.1:5000/

📍 Stage 2 — Routing & HTTP Methods

Flask lets you map URLs to Python functions.

Code: Multiple Routes

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route("/")
def index():
    return "Home Page"

@app.route("/about")
def about():
    return "About Page"

@app.route("/user/<username>")
def user_profile(username):
    return f"Profile of {username}"

@app.route("/post/<int:post_id>")
def post_detail(post_id):
    return f"Post ID: {post_id}"

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

Concepts here:

  • <username> → string by default

  • <int:post_id> → enforces integer type

📍 Stage 3 — Handling GET & POST

Flask’s request object gives you form data, query params, and JSON.

Code: GET and POST

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route("/echo", methods=["GET", "POST"])
def echo():
    if request.method == "GET":
        msg = request.args.get("msg", "No message")
        return f"GET message: {msg}"
    else:
        data = request.get_json()
        return jsonify({"POST message": data})

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

Test:

bash
curl "http://127.0.0.1:5000/echo?msg=Hello"
curl -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d '{"msg":"Hi"}' http://127.0.0.1:5000/echo

📍 Stage 5 — File Upload & Download

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
import os
from flask import Flask, request, send_from_directory

app = Flask(__name__)
UPLOAD_FOLDER = "uploads"
os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)

@app.route("/upload", methods=["POST"])
def upload_file():
    file = request.files["file"]
    file.save(os.path.join(UPLOAD_FOLDER, file.filename))
    return {"status": "uploaded"}

@app.route("/files/<filename>")
def serve_file(filename):
    return send_from_directory(UPLOAD_FOLDER, filename)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

📍 Stage 6 — JSON API + Frontend Fetch

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route("/api/add", methods=["POST"])
def add():
    data = request.get_json()
    result = data["a"] + data["b"]
    return jsonify({"sum": result})

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

javascript

You said:
Include cors
ChatGPT said:

Got it — if you’re going to hit your Flask backend from a frontend served on a different port/domain (like React at localhost:3000 or static HTML on another server), you’ll need CORS.

Flask doesn’t have it built in, but the flask-cors extension makes it easy.

📍 Step 1 — Install CORS support

bash
pip install flask-cors

📍 Step 2 — Add CORS to Your Flask App

Minimal Global CORS

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask, jsonify, request
from flask_cors import CORS

app = Flask(__name__)
CORS(app)  # Allow all domains for all routes

@app.route("/api/echo", methods=["POST"])
def echo():
    data = request.get_json()
    return jsonify({"you_sent": data})

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

Restrict to Certain Origins

python
CORS(app, resources={r"/api/*": {"origins": "http://localhost:3000"}})

This will:

  • Only allow requests to routes starting with /api/

  • Only accept requests from http://localhost:3000

Per-Route CORS

python
from flask_cors import cross_origin

@app.route("/public")
@cross_origin()  # Allow all origins
def public():
    return "This is public"

@app.route("/private")
@cross_origin(origins=["https://myapp.com"])
def private():
    return "Only https://myapp.com can call this"

Testing CORS

From a frontend JavaScript app:

javascript
fetch("http://127.0.0.1:5000/api/echo", {
  method: "POST",
  headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
  body: JSON.stringify({ msg: "Hello CORS" })
})
.then(r => r.json())
.then(console.log)
.catch(console.error);

manage.py (entry point)

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""Project entrypoint and cli helper."""
import os
from app import create_app, db, socketio
from flask_migrate import Migrate
from dotenv import load_dotenv

load_dotenv()  # load env vars from .env if present

app = create_app(os.getenv("FLASK_ENV", "development"))
migrate = Migrate(app, db)

# For dev: run with `python manage.py runserver`
def runserver():
    # socketio.run will use eventlet/async if installed for websockets
    socketio.run(app, host="0.0.0.0", port=5000, debug=app.config['DEBUG'])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import sys
    if len(sys.argv) >= 2 and sys.argv[1] == "runserver":
        runserver()
    else:
        # fallback to flask CLI comfort
        app.run(debug=app.config["DEBUG"])

app/__init__.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
App factory, blueprint registration, and global CORS setup.
"""
import os
from flask import Flask, jsonify
from .config import Config
from .extensions import db, cors, jwt, migrate, socketio
from .sockets import init_sockets

def create_app(env="development"):
    app = Flask(__name__, static_folder="../static", template_folder="templates")
    # Load config (can be extended to load multiple env files)
    app.config.from_object(Config)
    # override with env vars, if set
    app.config["SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI"] = os.getenv("DATABASE_URL", app.config["SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI"])
    app.config["JWT_SECRET_KEY"] = os.getenv("JWT_SECRET_KEY", app.config["JWT_SECRET_KEY"])

    # Initialize extensions
    db.init_app(app)
    migrate.init_app(app, db)
    jwt.init_app(app)

    # CORS: allow origins from env or default, restricted to /api/*
    cors.init_app(app, resources={r"/api/*": {"origins": app.config.get("CORS_ORIGINS", "*")}})

    # Register blueprints
    from .web.routes import web_bp
    from .api.routes import api_bp
    from .auth.routes import auth_bp
    app.register_blueprint(web_bp)
    app.register_blueprint(api_bp, url_prefix="/api")
    app.register_blueprint(auth_bp, url_prefix="/auth")

    # init socketio (pass app to bind later in manage.py with socketio.run)
    init_sockets(socketio, app)

    # simple health endpoint
    @app.route("/health")
    def health():
        return jsonify({"status": "ok"}), 200

    # error handlers
    @app.errorhandler(404)
    def not_found(e):
        return jsonify({"error": "Not Found"}), 404

    @app.errorhandler(500)
    def server_error(e):
        return jsonify({"error": "Internal Server Error"}), 500

    return app

app/config.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
import os

class Config:
    DEBUG = os.getenv("FLASK_ENV", "development") == "development"
    SECRET_KEY = os.getenv("SECRET_KEY", "dev-secret")
    SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI = os.getenv("DATABASE_URL", "sqlite:///data.db")
    SQLALCHEMY_TRACK_MODIFICATIONS = False
    JWT_SECRET_KEY = os.getenv("JWT_SECRET_KEY", "jwt-secret")
    # CORS_ORIGINS can be a comma separated list
    CORS_ORIGINS = os.getenv("CORS_ORIGINS", "*").split(",")

app/extensions.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask_sqlalchemy import SQLAlchemy
from flask_cors import CORS
from flask_jwt_extended import JWTManager
from flask_migrate import Migrate
from flask_socketio import SocketIO

db = SQLAlchemy()
cors = CORS()
jwt = JWTManager()
migrate = Migrate()
socketio = SocketIO(cors_allowed_origins="*")  # socketio CORS; tighten in prod

app/models.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from .extensions import db
from datetime import datetime
from werkzeug.security import generate_password_hash, check_password_hash

class User(db.Model):
    """Simple user model for JWT demo."""
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    username = db.Column(db.String(80), unique=True, nullable=False)
    password_hash = db.Column(db.String(128), nullable=False)
    created_at = db.Column(db.DateTime, default=datetime.utcnow)

    def set_password(self, password):
        self.password_hash = generate_password_hash(password)

    def check_password(self, password):
        return check_password_hash(self.password_hash, password)

    def to_dict(self):
        return {"id": self.id, "username": self.username}

app/auth/routes.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Blueprint, request, jsonify
from ..extensions import db
from ..models import User
from flask_jwt_extended import create_access_token

auth_bp = Blueprint("auth", __name__)

@auth_bp.route("/register", methods=["POST"])
def register():
    data = request.get_json() or {}
    username = data.get("username")
    password = data.get("password")
    if not username or not password:
        return jsonify({"msg":"username & password required"}), 400
    if User.query.filter_by(username=username).first():
        return jsonify({"msg":"user exists"}), 400
    user = User(username=username)
    user.set_password(password)
    db.session.add(user)
    db.session.commit()
    return jsonify({"msg":"registered", "user": user.to_dict()}), 201

@auth_bp.route("/login", methods=["POST"])
def login():
    data = request.get_json() or {}
    username = data.get("username")
    password = data.get("password")
    user = User.query.filter_by(username=username).first()
    if not user or not user.check_password(password):
        return jsonify({"msg":"bad credentials"}), 401
    token = create_access_token(identity=user.id)
    return jsonify({"access_token": token, "user": user.to_dict()})

app/api/routes.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Blueprint, request, jsonify, current_app, send_from_directory
from flask_jwt_extended import jwt_required, get_jwt_identity
from ..extensions import db
from ..models import User
import os
from werkzeug.utils import secure_filename

api_bp = Blueprint("api", __name__)

UPLOAD_DIR = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), "..", "uploads")
os.makedirs(UPLOAD_DIR, exist_ok=True)

@api_bp.route("/me")
@jwt_required()
def me():
    uid = get_jwt_identity()
    user = User.query.get(uid)
    return jsonify(user.to_dict())

@api_bp.route("/echo", methods=["POST"])
def echo():
    data = request.get_json() or {}
    return jsonify({"you_sent": data})

@api_bp.route("/upload", methods=["POST"])
def upload_file():
    if "file" not in request.files:
        return jsonify({"error":"no file part"}), 400
    f = request.files["file"]
    if f.filename == "":
        return jsonify({"error":"no selected file"}), 400
    filename = secure_filename(f.filename)
    path = os.path.join(UPLOAD_DIR, filename)
    f.save(path)
    return jsonify({"status":"uploaded", "filename": filename}), 201

@api_bp.route("/files/<path:filename>")
def download_file(filename):
    # send_from_directory handles streaming for large files
    return send_from_directory(UPLOAD_DIR, filename, as_attachment=True)

#!/usr/bin/env python3

app/sockets.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
Initialize SocketIO events. This example emits 'server_time' every second
for demonstration — in practice you'd emit events on file upload, jobs, etc.
"""
from flask_socketio import emit
from threading import Thread, Event
import time

def init_sockets(socketio, app):
    # Example: background thread that emits server time
    thread = None
    thread_stop = Event()

    @socketio.on("connect")
    def connected():
        emit("message", {"msg": "connected to socket"})

    def background():
        while not thread_stop.is_set():
            socketio.sleep(5)
            socketio.emit("server_time", {"time": time.strftime("%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S")})

    # start background thread once
    if thread is None:
        thread = socketio.start_background_task(target=background)

app/templates/index.html

html
<!doctype html>
<html>
  <head>
    <meta charset="utf-8">
    <title>Flask Training — Home</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <h1>Flask Training</h1>
    <p>Try the <a href="/auth/login">login page</a> or use the API at <code>/api/</code>.</p>

    <script>
      // Example fetch to CORS-enabled /api/echo
      async function testEcho() {
        const r = await fetch("/api/echo", {
          method: "POST",
          headers: {"Content-Type":"application/json"},
          body: JSON.stringify({msg: "Hello from front-end"})
        });
        const j = await r.json();
        console.log("echo:", j);
      }
      testEcho();
    </script>
  </body>
</html>

app/templates/login.html

html
<!doctype html>
<html>
<head><meta charset="utf-8"><title>Login</title></head>
<body>
  <h2>Login (demo)</h2>
  <form id="loginForm">
    <input name="username" placeholder="username" required>
    <input name="password" type="password" placeholder="password" required>
    <button type="submit">Login</button>
  </form>
  <script>
    document.getElementById("loginForm").addEventListener("submit", async (e) => {
      e.preventDefault();
      const fd = new FormData(e.target);
      const body = {username: fd.get("username"), password: fd.get("password")};
      const res = await fetch("/auth/login", {
        method: "POST",
        headers: {"Content-Type":"application/json"},
        body: JSON.stringify(body)
      });
      const data = await res.json();
      console.log("login response", data);
      if (data.access_token) {
        localStorage.setItem("token", data.access_token);
        alert("Login succeeded; token saved to localStorage.");
      } else alert("Login failed: " + JSON.stringify(data));
    });
  </script>
</body>
</html>

Dockerfile

dockerfile
# Use an official Python runtime as a parent image
FROM python:3.11-slim

WORKDIR /app
COPY requirements.txt ./
RUN pip install --no-cache-dir -r requirements.txt

COPY . /app
ENV FLASK_ENV=production
ENV FLASK_APP=manage.py

# Use eventlet for SocketIO
CMD ["gunicorn", "-k", "eventlet", "-w", "1", "--bind", "0.0.0.0:5000", "manage:app"]

      - JWT_SECRET_KEY=dev-jwt-secret
      - CORS_ORIGINS=http://localhost:3000

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
import pytest
from app import create_app
from app.extensions import db

@pytest.fixture
def app():
    app = create_app("testing")
    app.config["TESTING"] = True
    app.config["SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI"] = "sqlite:///:memory:"
    with app.app_context():
        db.create_all()
        yield app
        db.drop_all()

@pytest.fixture
def client(app):
    return app.test_client()

def test_health(client):
    r = client.get("/health")
    assert r.status_code == 200
    assert r.json["status"] == "ok"

How to run (quick start)

  1. Clone / create folder and paste code files.

  2. Create virtualenv and install:

bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash
python3 -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate
pip install -r requirements.txt

  1. Create .env (or set env vars), e.g. copy .env.example:

bash
cp .env.example .env
# edit .env to set JWT_SECRET_KEY & SECRET_KEY

  1. Initialize DB & migrations:

bash
export FLASK_APP=manage.py
flask db init
flask db migrate -m "init"
flask db upgrade

  1. Run dev server (with sockets):

bash
python manage.py runserver
# or
gunicorn -k eventlet -w 1 --bind 0.0.0.0:5000 manage:app

  1. Test:

  • GET /health → {status: ok}

  • POST /auth/register JSON {"username":"u","password":"p"} → register

  • POST /auth/login → get access_token

  • Use token to call protected endpoints:

    bash
    curl -H "Authorization: Bearer <token>" http://127.0.0.1:5000/api/me

  • Upload a file:

    bash
    curl -F "file=@./somefile.txt" http://127.0.0.1:5000/api/upload

  • Download:
    GET /api/files/somefile.txt

  1. WebSocket test (in browser console):

js
// include socket.io client from CDN or serve it locally
const s = io("http://127.0.0.1:5000");
s.on("connect", ()=>console.log("connected"));
s.on("server_time", (d)=>console.log("server_time", d));

3️⃣ app/init.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
Lesson 1 — App factory and basic routing
"""
from flask import Flask

def create_app():
    """
    Application factory function.
    Returns a Flask app instance.
    """
    app = Flask(__name__)

    # Import routes after app is created (avoids circular imports)
    from . import routes
    routes.init_app(app)

    return app

4️⃣ app/routes.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import request

def init_app(app):
    """Register routes on the given Flask app."""

    @app.route("/")
    def home():
        return "Hello, Flask!"

    @app.route("/hello/<name>")
    def hello_name(name):
        return f"Hello, {name}!"

    @app.route("/echo", methods=["GET"])
    def echo():
        """Example of reading query params: /echo?msg=hi"""
        msg = request.args.get("msg", "No message")
        return f"You said: {msg}"

5️⃣ manage.py (entry point)

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from app import create_app

app = create_app()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    # Debug=True enables live reload and better error pages
    app.run(debug=True)

6️⃣ Run the App

bash
# 1. Create & activate virtualenv
python3 -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate

# 2. Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt

# 3. Run
python manage.py

Visit:

  • http://127.0.0.1:5000/ → Hello, Flask!

  • http://127.0.0.1:5000/hello/Kirubakaran → Hello, Kirubakaran!

  • http://127.0.0.1:5000/echo?msg=Flask%20Rocks → You said: Flask Rocks

💡 Why This Structure?

  • App factory (create_app): lets us configure the app differently for dev, test, prod.

  • Routes in separate file (routes.py): avoids clutter in manage.py and prepares us for blueprints.

  • if __name__ == "__main__": allows running via Python directly and also under WSGI servers later.

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import request, render_template

def init_app(app):
    @app.route("/")
    def home():
        return "Hello, Flask!"

    @app.route("/hello/<name>")
    def hello_name(name):
        # Renders hello.html with variable 'name'
        return render_template("hello.html", name=name, title=f"Hello {name}")

    @app.route("/echo", methods=["GET"])
    def echo():
        msg = request.args.get("msg", "No message")
        return f"You said: {msg}"

Alright — Lesson 3: APIs + CORS
Now we make our Flask app talk to the outside world — JavaScript frontends, mobile apps, other services — without running into the dreaded “CORS policy blocked” error.

📍 Goal of Lesson 3

  • Build JSON API routes

  • Accept GET & POST requests with JSON

  • Enable CORS globally and per-route

  • Test API calls from JavaScript in a browser

1️⃣ Install flask-cors

bash
pip install flask-cors

2️⃣ Update app/__init__.py

We add CORS globally so all routes can be accessed from anywhere.
If you want restrictions, I’ll show that below.

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask
from flask_cors import CORS

def create_app():
    app = Flask(__name__)
    
    # Enable CORS for all routes & origins
    CORS(app)

    # Import and register routes
    from .routes import init_app
    init_app(app)

    return app

3️⃣ Add JSON API routes to routes.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import request, jsonify, render_template
from flask_cors import cross_origin

def init_app(app):

    @app.route("/")
    def home():
        return "Hello, Flask!"

    @app.route("/hello/<name>")
    def hello_name(name):
        return render_template("hello.html", name=name, title=f"Hello {name}")

    # ✅ JSON GET example
    @app.route("/api/greet", methods=["GET"])
    def api_greet():
        name = request.args.get("name", "Guest")
        return jsonify({"message": f"Hello, {name}!"})

    # ✅ JSON POST example
    @app.route("/api/echo", methods=["POST"])
    def api_echo():
        data = request.get_json()
        return jsonify({"you_sent": data})

    # ✅ Per-route CORS example (only allow localhost:3000)
    @app.route("/api/secure-data")
    @cross_origin(origins="http://localhost:3000")
    def secure_data():
        return jsonify({"status": "ok", "data": [1, 2, 3]})

4️⃣ Test with JavaScript (frontend example)

Make a test.html in your static/ folder:

html

    <title>Flask CORS Test</title>
</head>
<body>
    <h1>Testing Flask API + CORS</h1>
    <button onclick="getData()">Test API</button>

    <script>
    function getData() {
        fetch("http://127.0.0.1:5000/api/greet?name=Kirubakaran")
            .then(res => res.json())
            .then(data => console.log(data))
            .catch(err => console.error(err));

    </script>

Open this file from any origin (even a different port) — the response should appear in the browser console.

5️⃣ Restrict CORS (optional)

If you only want a certain frontend to call your API:

python
from flask_cors import CORS
CORS(app, resources={r"/api/*": {"origins": "http://localhost:3000"}})

This allows /api/* endpoints to be called only from localhost:3000.

💡 Concepts Learned

  • jsonify() returns proper JSON responses with Content-Type: application/json

  • CORS prevents frontend JS from calling other domains unless explicitly allowed

  • flask-cors makes it easy to allow all or specific origins

  • Can enable globally or per route

Alright — Lesson 4: Forms & File Uploads in Flask
Now we’ll let users send data and files to our server — both through an HTML form and via an API.

📍 Goal of Lesson 4

  • Accept HTML form submissions

  • Handle file uploads

  • Support upload via API (JSON + file)

1️⃣ Create an uploads folder

In your project root:

bash
mkdir uploads

Flask will save incoming files here.

2️⃣ Update app/__init__.py

Add UPLOAD_FOLDER configuration.

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask
from flask_cors import CORS
import os

def create_app():
    app = Flask(__name__)
    
    # Config
    app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"] = os.path.join(os.getcwd(), "uploads")
    os.makedirs(app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"], exist_ok=True)
    
    # Enable CORS globally
    CORS(app)

    from .routes import init_app
    init_app(app)

    return app

3️⃣ Update routes.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import request, jsonify, render_template, current_app
from werkzeug.utils import secure_filename
import os

def init_app(app):

    @app.route("/")
    def home():
        return "Hello, Flask!"

    # ✅ HTML form page for uploads
    @app.route("/upload", methods=["GET"])
    def upload_form():
        return render_template("upload.html", title="Upload File")

    # ✅ Handle file upload from HTML form
    @app.route("/upload", methods=["POST"])
    def upload_file():
        if "file" not in request.files:
            return "No file part", 400
        
        file = request.files["file"]
        if file.filename == "":
            return "No selected file", 400
        
        filename = secure_filename(file.filename)
        save_path = os.path.join(current_app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"], filename)
        file.save(save_path)
        
        return f"File uploaded: {filename} (Saved to uploads/)"

    # ✅ API: Upload file via POST
    @app.route("/api/upload", methods=["POST"])
    def api_upload():
        if "file" not in request.files:
            return jsonify({"error": "No file uploaded"}), 400
        
        file = request.files["file"]
        filename = secure_filename(file.filename)
        save_path = os.path.join(current_app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"], filename)
        file.save(save_path)

        return jsonify({
            "status": "success",
            "filename": filename,
            "path": save_path
        })

Alright — Lesson 5: Database Integration & CRUD API in Flask
Now we’ll store and retrieve data using SQLite — perfect for learning database concepts in Flask before moving to MySQL/PostgreSQL.

📍 Goal of Lesson 5

  • Connect Flask to SQLite using SQLAlchemy

  • Create a model (Item)

  • Implement CRUD routes:

    • Create (POST)

    • Read (GET)

    • Update (PUT)

    • Delete (DELETE)

1️⃣ Install SQLAlchemy

bash
pip install flask-sqlalchemy

2️⃣ Update app/__init__.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask
from flask_cors import CORS
from flask_sqlalchemy import SQLAlchemy
import os

db = SQLAlchemy()

def create_app():
    app = Flask(__name__)
    
    # Config
    BASE_DIR = os.path.abspath(os.path.dirname(__file__))
    DB_PATH = os.path.join(BASE_DIR, "data.db")
    app.config["SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI"] = f"sqlite:///{DB_PATH}"
    app.config["SQLALCHEMY_TRACK_MODIFICATIONS"] = False
    app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"] = os.path.join(os.getcwd(), "uploads")
    os.makedirs(app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"], exist_ok=True)

    # Enable CORS globally
    CORS(app)

    # Init DB
    db.init_app(app)

    from .routes import init_app
    init_app(app, db)

    return app

3️⃣ Create models.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from . import db

class Item(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    name = db.Column(db.String(120), nullable=False)
    description = db.Column(db.String(250), nullable=True)

    def to_dict(self):
        return {"id": self.id, "name": self.name, "description": self.description}

4️⃣ Update routes.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import request, jsonify, render_template, current_app
from werkzeug.utils import secure_filename
import os
from .models import Item

def init_app(app, db):

    @app.route("/")
    def home():
        return "Hello, Flask + SQLite!"

    # ========== CRUD ROUTES ==========
    @app.route("/api/items", methods=["GET"])
    def get_items():
        items = Item.query.all()
        return jsonify([i.to_dict() for i in items])

    @app.route("/api/items/<int:item_id>", methods=["GET"])
    def get_item(item_id):
        item = Item.query.get_or_404(item_id)
        return jsonify(item.to_dict())

    @app.route("/api/items", methods=["POST"])
    def create_item():
        data = request.json
        new_item = Item(name=data["name"], description=data.get("description"))
        db.session.add(new_item)
        db.session.commit()
        return jsonify(new_item.to_dict()), 201

    @app.route("/api/items/<int:item_id>", methods=["PUT"])
    def update_item(item_id):
        item = Item.query.get_or_404(item_id)
        data = request.json
        item.name = data.get("name", item.name)
        item.description = data.get("description", item.description)
        db.session.commit()
        return jsonify(item.to_dict())

    @app.route("/api/items/<int:item_id>", methods=["DELETE"])
    def delete_item(item_id):
        item = Item.query.get_or_404(item_id)
        db.session.delete(item)
        db.session.commit()
        return jsonify({"status": "deleted"})

4️⃣ JavaScript (static/script.js)

javascript
const API_URL = "/api/items";
const itemList = document.getElementById("itemList");
const itemForm = document.getElementById("itemForm");

async function fetchItems() {
    const res = await fetch(API_URL);
    const items = await res.json();
    itemList.innerHTML = "";
    items.forEach(item => addItemToDOM(item));
}

function addItemToDOM(item) {
    const li = document.createElement("li");
    li.className = "list-group-item d-flex justify-content-between align-items-center";
    li.innerHTML = `
        <span><strong>${item.name}</strong>: ${item.description || ""}</span>
        <div>
            <button class="btn btn-sm btn-warning me-2" onclick="editItem(${item.id})">Edit</button>
            <button class="btn btn-sm btn-danger" onclick="deleteItem(${item.id})">Delete</button>
        </div>
    `;
    itemList.appendChild(li);
}

itemForm.addEventListener("submit", async (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    const name = document.getElementById("name").value.trim();
    const description = document.getElementById("description").value.trim();
    const res = await fetch(API_URL, {
        method: "POST",
        headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
        body: JSON.stringify({ name, description })
    });
    const newItem = await res.json();
    addItemToDOM(newItem);
    itemForm.reset();
});

async function deleteItem(id) {
    await fetch(`${API_URL}/${id}`, { method: "DELETE" });
    fetchItems();
}

async function editItem(id) {
    const name = prompt("Enter new name:");
    const description = prompt("Enter new description:");
    if (name) {
        await fetch(`${API_URL}/${id}`, {
            method: "PUT",
            headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
            body: JSON.stringify({ name, description })
        });
        fetchItems();
    }
}

fetchItems();

#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask_sqlalchemy import SQLAlchemy

db = SQLAlchemy()

class Item(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    name = db.Column(db.String(120), nullable=False)
    description = db.Column(db.String(500))
    image = db.Column(db.String(200))  # store file path

    def to_dict(self):

            "name": self.name,
            "description": self.description,
            "image": self.image

2️⃣ Update Routes for File Uploads

app/routes.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import request, jsonify, render_template, current_app, send_from_directory
from werkzeug.utils import secure_filename
import os
from .models import Item, db

UPLOAD_FOLDER = "uploads"
ALLOWED_EXTENSIONS = {"png", "jpg", "jpeg", "gif"}

def allowed_file(filename):
    return '.' in filename and filename.rsplit('.', 1)[1].lower() in ALLOWED_EXTENSIONS

def init_app(app, db):
    app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"] = UPLOAD_FOLDER
    os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)

    @app.route("/")
    def home():
        return render_template("index.html")

    @app.route("/uploads/<filename>")
    def uploaded_file(filename):
        return send_from_directory(app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"], filename)

    @app.route("/api/items", methods=["GET"])
    def get_items():
        items = Item.query.all()
        return jsonify([i.to_dict() for i in items])

    @app.route("/api/items", methods=["POST"])
    def create_item():
        name = request.form.get("name")
        description = request.form.get("description")
        image_file = request.files.get("image")

        image_path = None
        if image_file and allowed_file(image_file.filename):
            filename = secure_filename(image_file.filename)
            image_file.save(os.path.join(app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"], filename))
            image_path = f"/uploads/{filename}"

        new_item = Item(name=name, description=description, image=image_path)
        db.session.add(new_item)
        db.session.commit()
        return jsonify(new_item.to_dict()), 201

    @app.route("/api/items/<int:item_id>", methods=["DELETE"])
    def delete_item(item_id):
        item = Item.query.get_or_404(item_id)
        db.session.delete(item)
        db.session.commit()
        return jsonify({"status": "deleted"})

    `;

}

        method: "POST",
        body: formData
    });
    const newItem = await res.json();
    addItemToDOM(newItem);
    itemForm.reset();
});

    await fetch(`${API_URL}/${id}`, { method: "DELETE" });
    fetchItems();
}

Alright — Lesson 8: Search, Pagination & Image Lightbox in Flask
In this lesson, we’ll upgrade our app so users can:

  1. Search items by name or description

  2. Paginate results for large datasets

  3. Click an image to view it in full size in a lightbox

📍 Goal of Lesson 8

  • Add /api/items GET parameters search and page

  • Return paginated JSON results

  • Update the frontend to support search + next/prev buttons

  • Implement Bootstrap lightbox for image preview

1️⃣ Update API to Support Search & Pagination

app/routes.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import request, jsonify, render_template, current_app, send_from_directory
from werkzeug.utils import secure_filename
from sqlalchemy import or_
import os
from .models import Item, db

UPLOAD_FOLDER = "uploads"
ALLOWED_EXTENSIONS = {"png", "jpg", "jpeg", "gif"}
ITEMS_PER_PAGE = 5

def allowed_file(filename):
    return '.' in filename and filename.rsplit('.', 1)[1].lower() in ALLOWED_EXTENSIONS

def init_app(app, db):
    app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"] = UPLOAD_FOLDER
    os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)

    @app.route("/")
    def home():
        return render_template("index.html")

    @app.route("/uploads/<filename>")
    def uploaded_file(filename):
        return send_from_directory(app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"], filename)

    @app.route("/api/items", methods=["GET"])
    def get_items():
        search = request.args.get("search", "").strip()
        page = int(request.args.get("page", 1))

        query = Item.query
        if search:
            query = query.filter(or_(
                Item.name.ilike(f"%{search}%"),
                Item.description.ilike(f"%{search}%")
            ))

        total = query.count()
        items = query.order_by(Item.id.desc()).paginate(page=page, per_page=ITEMS_PER_PAGE, error_out=False).items

        return jsonify({
            "items": [i.to_dict() for i in items],
            "total": total,
            "page": page,
            "pages": (total + ITEMS_PER_PAGE - 1) // ITEMS_PER_PAGE
        })

    @app.route("/api/items", methods=["POST"])
    def create_item():
        name = request.form.get("name")
        description = request.form.get("description")
        image_file = request.files.get("image")

        image_path = None
        if image_file and allowed_file(image_file.filename):
            filename = secure_filename(image_file.filename)
            image_file.save(os.path.join(app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"], filename))
            image_path = f"/uploads/{filename}"

        new_item = Item(name=name, description=description, image=image_path)
        db.session.add(new_item)
        db.session.commit()
        return jsonify(new_item.to_dict()), 201

    @app.route("/api/items/<int:item_id>", methods=["DELETE"])
    def delete_item(item_id):
        item = Item.query.get_or_404(item_id)
        db.session.delete(item)
        db.session.commit()
        return jsonify({"status": "deleted"})

    <button id="nextBtn" class="btn btn-secondary btn-sm" disabled>Next</button>
</div>

<!-- Lightbox Modal -->
<div class="modal fade" id="lightboxModal" tabindex="-1">
    <div class="modal-dialog modal-dialog-centered">

            <img id="lightboxImage" class="img-fluid rounded">
        </div>
    </div>
</div>

3️⃣ Update JavaScript

static/script.js

javascript
const API_URL = "/api/items";
const itemList = document.getElementById("itemList");
const searchBox = document.getElementById("searchBox");
const prevBtn = document.getElementById("prevBtn");
const nextBtn = document.getElementById("nextBtn");

let currentPage = 1;
let totalPages = 1;
let currentSearch = "";

async function fetchItems() {
    const res = await fetch(`${API_URL}?search=${encodeURIComponent(currentSearch)}&page=${currentPage}`);
    const data = await res.json();
    totalPages = data.pages;

    itemList.innerHTML = "";
    data.items.forEach(item => addItemToDOM(item));

    prevBtn.disabled = currentPage <= 1;
    nextBtn.disabled = currentPage >= totalPages;
}

function addItemToDOM(item) {
    const li = document.createElement("li");
    li.className = "list-group-item";
    li.innerHTML = `
        <div class="d-flex align-items-center">
            ${item.image ? `<img src="${item.image}" class="me-3 rounded clickable-img" width="60" height="60">` : ""}
            <div class="flex-grow-1">
                <strong>${item.name}</strong><br>
                ${item.description || ""}
            </div>
            <button class="btn btn-sm btn-danger ms-2" onclick="deleteItem(${item.id})">Delete</button>
        </div>
    `;
    itemList.appendChild(li);

    if (item.image) {
        li.querySelector(".clickable-img").addEventListener("click", () => {
            document.getElementById("lightboxImage").src = item.image;
            new bootstrap.Modal(document.getElementById("lightboxModal")).show();
        });
    }
}

searchBox.addEventListener("input", () => {
    currentSearch = searchBox.value;
    currentPage = 1;
    fetchItems();
});

prevBtn.addEventListener("click", () => {
    if (currentPage > 1) {
        currentPage--;
        fetchItems();
    }
});

nextBtn.addEventListener("click", () => {
    if (currentPage < totalPages) {
        currentPage++;
        fetchItems();
    }
});

async function deleteItem(id) {
    await fetch(`${API_URL}/${id}`, { method: "DELETE" });
    fetchItems();
}

fetchItems();

Alright — Lesson 9: User Authentication (Login & Protected Routes)
In this lesson, we’ll add user accounts, so only logged-in users can create or delete items, while everyone can view them.

📍 Goal of Lesson 9

  • Add a User model with hashed passwords

  • Implement register and login endpoints

  • Use Flask-Login for session management

  • Protect API routes so only authenticated users can modify data

1️⃣ Install Requirements

bash
pip install flask-login flask-bcrypt

2️⃣ Update Database Models

app/models.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask_sqlalchemy import SQLAlchemy
from flask_login import UserMixin
from flask_bcrypt import generate_password_hash, check_password_hash

db = SQLAlchemy()

class User(UserMixin, db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    username = db.Column(db.String(80), unique=True, nullable=False)
    password_hash = db.Column(db.String(200), nullable=False)

    def set_password(self, password):
        self.password_hash = generate_password_hash(password).decode('utf-8')

    def check_password(self, password):
        return check_password_hash(self.password_hash, password)

class Item(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    name = db.Column(db.String(120), nullable=False)
    description = db.Column(db.String(500))
    image = db.Column(db.String(200))

    def to_dict(self):
        return {
            "id": self.id,
            "name": self.name,
            "description": self.description,
            "image": self.image
        }

3️⃣ Update Routes for Auth

app/routes.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import request, jsonify, render_template, send_from_directory
from flask_login import LoginManager, login_user, login_required, logout_user, current_user
from werkzeug.utils import secure_filename
import os
from .models import db, Item, User

UPLOAD_FOLDER = "uploads"
ALLOWED_EXTENSIONS = {"png", "jpg", "jpeg", "gif"}

login_manager = LoginManager()

def allowed_file(filename):
    return '.' in filename and filename.rsplit('.', 1)[1].lower() in ALLOWED_EXTENSIONS

@login_manager.user_loader
def load_user(user_id):
    return User.query.get(int(user_id))

def init_app(app, db):
    app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"] = UPLOAD_FOLDER
    os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)

    login_manager.init_app(app)
    login_manager.login_view = "login"

    @app.route("/")
    def home():
        return render_template("index.html")

    @app.route("/uploads/<filename>")
    def uploaded_file(filename):
        return send_from_directory(app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"], filename)

    # --- Auth APIs ---
    @app.route("/api/register", methods=["POST"])
    def register():
        data = request.json
        if User.query.filter_by(username=data["username"]).first():
            return jsonify({"error": "Username exists"}), 400
        user = User(username=data["username"])
        user.set_password(data["password"])
        db.session.add(user)
        db.session.commit()
        return jsonify({"status": "registered"})

    @app.route("/api/login", methods=["POST"])
    def login():
        data = request.json
        user = User.query.filter_by(username=data["username"]).first()
        if user and user.check_password(data["password"]):
            login_user(user)
            return jsonify({"status": "logged_in"})
        return jsonify({"error": "Invalid credentials"}), 401

    @app.route("/api/logout", methods=["POST"])
    @login_required
    def logout():
        logout_user()
        return jsonify({"status": "logged_out"})

    # --- Items API ---
    @app.route("/api/items", methods=["GET"])
    def get_items():
        items = Item.query.all()
        return jsonify([i.to_dict() for i in items])

    @app.route("/api/items", methods=["POST"])
    @login_required
    def create_item():
        name = request.form.get("name")
        description = request.form.get("description")
        image_file = request.files.get("image")

        image_path = None
        if image_file and allowed_file(image_file.filename):
            filename = secure_filename(image_file.filename)
            image_file.save(os.path.join(app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"], filename))
            image_path = f"/uploads/{filename}"

        new_item = Item(name=name, description=description, image=image_path)
        db.session.add(new_item)
        db.session.commit()
        return jsonify(new_item.to_dict()), 201

    @app.route("/api/items/<int:item_id>", methods=["DELETE"])
    @login_required
    def delete_item(item_id):
        item = Item.query.get_or_404(item_id)
        db.session.delete(item)
        db.session.commit()
        return jsonify({"status": "deleted"})

async function login(username, password) {

        method: "POST",
        headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
        body: JSON.stringify({ username, password })
    });

    const res = await fetch("/api/register", {
        method: "POST",
        headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
        body: JSON.stringify({ username, password })
    });
    return res.ok;
}

    const pass = document.getElementById("password").value;

#!/usr/bin/env python3
from . import db
from datetime import datetime

class User(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    username = db.Column(db.String(80), unique=True, nullable=False)
    password = db.Column(db.String(200), nullable=False)

class Item(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)

3️⃣ Update app/__init__.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask
from flask_cors import CORS
from flask_sqlalchemy import SQLAlchemy
from flask_bcrypt import Bcrypt
from flask_jwt_extended import JWTManager
import os

db = SQLAlchemy()
bcrypt = Bcrypt()
jwt = JWTManager()

def create_app():
    app = Flask(__name__)

    # Config
    BASE_DIR = os.path.abspath(os.path.dirname(__file__))
    DB_PATH = os.path.join(BASE_DIR, "data.db")
    app.config["SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI"] = f"sqlite:///{DB_PATH}"
    app.config["SQLALCHEMY_TRACK_MODIFICATIONS"] = False
    app.config["JWT_SECRET_KEY"] = "super-secret-key"  # Change in production
    app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"] = os.path.join(os.getcwd(), "uploads")
    os.makedirs(app.config["UPLOAD_FOLDER"], exist_ok=True)

    # Extensions
    CORS(app)
    db.init_app(app)
    bcrypt.init_app(app)
    jwt.init_app(app)

    from .routes import init_app
    init_app(app, db, bcrypt)

    return app

4️⃣ Update routes.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import request, jsonify
from flask_jwt_extended import create_access_token, jwt_required
from .models import User, Item

def init_app(app, db, bcrypt):

    @app.route("/register", methods=["POST"])
    def register():
        data = request.json
        username = data.get("username")
        password = data.get("password")

        if not username or not password:
            return jsonify({"error": "Username and password required"}), 400

        if User.query.filter_by(username=username).first():
            return jsonify({"error": "Username already exists"}), 400

        hashed_pw = bcrypt.generate_password_hash(password).decode("utf-8")
        user = User(username=username, password=hashed_pw)
        db.session.add(user)
        db.session.commit()

        return jsonify({"message": "User registered successfully"})

    @app.route("/login", methods=["POST"])
    def login():
        data = request.json
        user = User.query.filter_by(username=data.get("username")).first()
        if user and bcrypt.check_password_hash(user.password, data.get("password")):
            token = create_access_token(identity=user.username)
            return jsonify({"token": token})
        return jsonify({"error": "Invalid credentials"}), 401

    # Protected route example
    @app.route("/api/items", methods=["POST"])
    @jwt_required()
    def create_item():
        data = request.json
        new_item = Item(name=data["name"], description=data.get("description"))
        db.session.add(new_item)
        db.session.commit()
        return jsonify(new_item.to_dict()), 201

    @app.route("/api/items", methods=["GET"])
    def get_items():
        items = Item.query.all()
        return jsonify([i.to_dict() for i in items])

Alright — Lesson 11: Role-Based Authorization in Flask
Now that we have authentication working, we’ll add roles so certain actions are restricted to admin users.

📍 Goal of Lesson 11

  • Add a role field to the User model

  • Assign roles during registration

  • Create a custom decorator for role checking

  • Restrict certain routes (e.g., deleting an item) to admins only

1️⃣ Update models.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from . import db
from datetime import datetime

class User(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    username = db.Column(db.String(80), unique=True, nullable=False)
    password = db.Column(db.String(200), nullable=False)
    role = db.Column(db.String(20), default="user")  # new field
    created_at = db.Column(db.DateTime, default=datetime.utcnow)

class Item(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    name = db.Column(db.String(120), nullable=False)
    description = db.Column(db.String(250), nullable=True)

    def to_dict(self):
        return {"id": self.id, "name": self.name, "description": self.description}

2️⃣ Create a Role Check Decorator

Create decorators.py:

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import jsonify
from flask_jwt_extended import get_jwt_identity
from functools import wraps
from .models import User
from . import db

def role_required(role):
    def wrapper(fn):
        @wraps(fn)
        def decorated(*args, **kwargs):
            current_user = get_jwt_identity()
            user = User.query.filter_by(username=current_user).first()
            if not user or user.role != role:
                return jsonify({"error": "Forbidden - Admins only"}), 403
            return fn(*args, **kwargs)
        return decorated
    return wrapper

3️⃣ Update routes.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import request, jsonify
from flask_jwt_extended import create_access_token, jwt_required, get_jwt_identity
from .models import User, Item
from .decorators import role_required

def init_app(app, db, bcrypt):

    @app.route("/register", methods=["POST"])
    def register():
        data = request.json
        username = data.get("username")
        password = data.get("password")
        role = data.get("role", "user")  # Allow role assignment for testing

        if not username or not password:
            return jsonify({"error": "Username and password required"}), 400

        if User.query.filter_by(username=username).first():
            return jsonify({"error": "Username already exists"}), 400

        hashed_pw = bcrypt.generate_password_hash(password).decode("utf-8")
        user = User(username=username, password=hashed_pw, role=role)
        db.session.add(user)
        db.session.commit()

        return jsonify({"message": "User registered successfully"})

    @app.route("/login", methods=["POST"])
    def login():
        data = request.json
        user = User.query.filter_by(username=data.get("username")).first()
        if user and bcrypt.check_password_hash(user.password, data.get("password")):
            token = create_access_token(identity=user.username)
            return jsonify({"token": token})
        return jsonify({"error": "Invalid credentials"}), 401

    # Protected route for normal users
    @app.route("/api/items", methods=["POST"])
    @jwt_required()
    def create_item():
        data = request.json
        new_item = Item(name=data["name"], description=data.get("description"))
        db.session.add(new_item)
        db.session.commit()
        return jsonify(new_item.to_dict()), 201

    @app.route("/api/items", methods=["GET"])
    def get_items():
        items = Item.query.all()
        return jsonify([i.to_dict() for i in items])

    # Admin-only route
    @app.route("/api/items/<int:item_id>", methods=["DELETE"])
    @jwt_required()
    @role_required("admin")
    def delete_item(item_id):
        item = Item.query.get_or_404(item_id)
        db.session.delete(item)
        db.session.commit()
        return jsonify({"message": "Item deleted"})

Alright — Lesson 12: File Uploads & Secure File Serving in Flask
Now we’ll implement file uploads with authentication and role restrictions so only certain users (like admins) can upload files, while regular users can only view/download.

📍 Goal of Lesson 12

  • Create a file upload API

  • Store uploaded files in a safe directory

  • Allow admins to upload, but everyone logged in to download

  • Prevent directory traversal attacks (../../etc/passwd kind of paths)

  • Return file lists securely

1️⃣ Project Structure Update

bash
flask_training/
│
├── app/
│   ├── __init__.py
│   ├── routes.py
│   ├── models.py
│   ├── decorators.py
│   ├── uploads/   # New: Store uploaded files here

2️⃣ Update routes.py

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
import os
from flask import request, jsonify, send_from_directory
from flask_jwt_extended import jwt_required
from werkzeug.utils import secure_filename
from .models import Item
from .decorators import role_required

UPLOAD_FOLDER = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), "uploads")
ALLOWED_EXTENSIONS = {"png", "jpg", "jpeg", "gif", "txt", "pdf"}

# Ensure uploads folder exists
os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)

def allowed_file(filename):
    return "." in filename and filename.rsplit(".", 1)[1].lower() in ALLOWED_EXTENSIONS

def init_app(app, db, bcrypt):

    # Existing routes remain...

    # Admin-only file upload
    @app.route("/upload", methods=["POST"])
    @jwt_required()
    @role_required("admin")
    def upload_file():
        if "file" not in request.files:
            return jsonify({"error": "No file part"}), 400

        file = request.files["file"]

        if file.filename == "":
            return jsonify({"error": "No selected file"}), 400

        if file and allowed_file(file.filename):
            filename = secure_filename(file.filename)
            file.save(os.path.join(UPLOAD_FOLDER, filename))
            return jsonify({"message": f"File '{filename}' uploaded successfully"}), 201
        else:
            return jsonify({"error": "Invalid file type"}), 400

    # List uploaded files (all logged-in users)
    @app.route("/files", methods=["GET"])
    @jwt_required()
    def list_files():
        files = os.listdir(UPLOAD_FOLDER)
        return jsonify(files)

    # Download a file (all logged-in users)
    @app.route("/files/<filename>", methods=["GET"])
    @jwt_required()
    def get_file(filename):
        safe_filename = secure_filename(filename)
        file_path = os.path.join(UPLOAD_FOLDER, safe_filename)
        if not os.path.exists(file_path):
            return jsonify({"error": "File not found"}), 404
        return send_from_directory(UPLOAD_FOLDER, safe_filename, as_attachment=True)

http://127.0.0.1:5000/files/test.txt --output downloaded.txt

  • File extension whitelist to prevent uploading dangerous files (.exe, .sh, etc.)

  • Files are served only to authenticated users

  • Upload permissions limited to admins

Alright — Lesson 13: REST API with Pagination, Search & Sorting
This will make our Item model API production-friendly by allowing clients to:

  • Paginate results (avoid sending thousands of records at once)

  • Search by name or description

  • Sort by price, name, or date

📍 Goal of Lesson 13

Enhance /items GET route to support:

pgsql
GET /items?page=1&limit=5&search=book&sort=price&order=desc

Where:

  • page → which page number to return

  • limit → items per page

  • search → text search in name or description

  • sort → field to sort by

  • order → asc or desc

1️⃣ Updated /items route

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import request, jsonify
from flask_jwt_extended import jwt_required
from sqlalchemy import asc, desc
from .models import Item

def init_app(app, db, bcrypt):

    # Other routes...

    @app.route("/items", methods=["GET"])
    @jwt_required()
    def get_items():
        # Query parameters
        page = int(request.args.get("page", 1))
        limit = int(request.args.get("limit", 10))
        search = request.args.get("search", "")
        sort = request.args.get("sort", "id")
        order = request.args.get("order", "asc").lower()

        # Base query
        query = Item.query

        # Search filter
        if search:
            query = query.filter(
                (Item.name.ilike(f"%{search}%")) |
                (Item.description.ilike(f"%{search}%"))
            )

        # Sorting
        if hasattr(Item, sort):
            sort_col = getattr(Item, sort)
            query = query.order_by(desc(sort_col) if order == "desc" else asc(sort_col))

        # Pagination
        total_items = query.count()
        items = query.offset((page - 1) * limit).limit(limit).all()

        # Return paginated result
        return jsonify({
            "page": page,
            "limit": limit,
            "total_items": total_items,
            "total_pages": (total_items + limit - 1) // limit,
            "data": [
                {"id": i.id, "name": i.name, "description": i.description, "price": i.price}
                for i in items
            ]
        })

bash

"http://127.0.0.1:5000/items?search=Book"

Sort by Price Descending

bash

"http://127.0.0.1:5000/items?sort=price&order=desc"

3️⃣ Key Points Learned

  • request.args.get() for query parameters

  • SQLAlchemy .filter() with ilike for case-insensitive search

  • order_by(asc(...)) / order_by(desc(...)) for sorting

  • Pagination using .offset() and .limit()

  • Returning structured JSON with metadata (total_items, total_pages)

2️⃣ Flask Route to Serve HTML

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask, render_template, jsonify, request
from flask_jwt_extended import jwt_required
from models import Item

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route("/")
def home():
    return render_template("index.html")

# This is your existing paginated API route from Lesson 13
@app.route("/items", methods=["GET"])
@jwt_required()
def get_items():
    page = int(request.args.get("page", 1))
    limit = int(request.args.get("limit", 10))
    search = request.args.get("search", "")
    sort = request.args.get("sort", "id")
    order = request.args.get("order", "asc").lower()

    query = Item.query
    if search:
        query = query.filter(
            (Item.name.ilike(f"%{search}%")) |
            (Item.description.ilike(f"%{search}%"))
        )

    if hasattr(Item, sort):
        sort_col = getattr(Item, sort)
        query = query.order_by(
            sort_col.desc() if order == "desc" else sort_col.asc()
        )

    total_items = query.count()
    items = query.offset((page - 1) * limit).limit(limit).all()

    return jsonify({
        "page": page,
        "limit": limit,
        "total_items": total_items,
        "total_pages": (total_items + limit - 1) // limit,
        "data": [
            {"id": i.id, "name": i.name, "description": i.description, "price": i.price}
            for i in items
        ]
    })

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

4️⃣ static/script.js

javascript
let token = ""; // <-- Put your JWT token here for now

async function loadItems(page = 1) {
    const search = document.getElementById("search").value;
    const sort = document.getElementById("sort").value;
    const order = document.getElementById("order").value;

    const url = `/items?page=${page}&limit=5&search=${search}&sort=${sort}&order=${order}`;

    const res = await fetch(url, {
        headers: { "Authorization": `Bearer ${token}` }
    });
    const data = await res.json();

    const tableBody = document.getElementById("itemTable");
    tableBody.innerHTML = "";

    data.data.forEach(item => {
        const row = `<tr>
            <td>${item.id}</td>
            <td>${item.name}</td>
            <td>${item.description}</td>
            <td>${item.price}</td>
        </tr>`;
        tableBody.innerHTML += row;
    });

    // Pagination controls
    const pagination = document.getElementById("pagination");
    pagination.innerHTML = "";
    for (let i = 1; i <= data.total_pages; i++) {
        pagination.innerHTML += `<button onclick="loadItems(${i})">${i}</button>`;
    }
}

document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", () => {
    loadItems();
});

Alright — Lesson 15: Adding Login & JWT Token Storage in Front-End
This is where we make the UI actually authenticate with the Flask backend, so users don’t have to manually paste a token into script.js.

📍 Goal of Lesson 15

  • Add a login form to the HTML

  • Call Flask /login endpoint to get JWT token

  • Store JWT token in localStorage

  • Use that token for all future API requests

  • Redirect user to item listing after login

1️⃣ Flask /login Endpoint

We already built a /login in Lesson 10 (JWT auth).
Here’s a recap, with a small tweak to support our front end:

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
from flask_jwt_extended import JWTManager, create_access_token
from werkzeug.security import check_password_hash
from models import User

app = Flask(__name__)
app.config["JWT_SECRET_KEY"] = "super-secret"  # change in production
jwt = JWTManager(app)

@app.route("/login", methods=["POST"])
def login():
    data = request.get_json()
    username = data.get("username")
    password = data.get("password")

    user = User.query.filter_by(username=username).first()
    if not user or not check_password_hash(user.password, password):
        return jsonify({"msg": "Invalid username or password"}), 401

    token = create_access_token(identity=username)
    return jsonify({"access_token": token})

3️⃣ Updated JS (static/script.js)

javascript
async function login() {
    const username = document.getElementById("username").value;
    const password = document.getElementById("password").value;

    const res = await fetch("/login", {
        method: "POST",
        headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
        body: JSON.stringify({ username, password })
    });

    if (res.ok) {
        const data = await res.json();
        localStorage.setItem("jwt", data.access_token);
        document.getElementById("loginSection").style.display = "none";
        document.getElementById("itemSection").style.display = "block";
        loadItems();
    } else {
        document.getElementById("loginMsg").textContent = "Login failed!";
    }
}

async function loadItems(page = 1) {
    const token = localStorage.getItem("jwt");
    if (!token) return;

    const search = document.getElementById("search").value;
    const sort = document.getElementById("sort").value;
    const order = document.getElementById("order").value;

    const url = `/items?page=${page}&limit=5&search=${search}&sort=${sort}&order=${order}`;

    const res = await fetch(url, {
        headers: { "Authorization": `Bearer ${token}` }
    });

    if (res.status === 401) {
        localStorage.removeItem("jwt");
        location.reload();
        return;
    }

    const data = await res.json();
    const tableBody = document.getElementById("itemTable");
    tableBody.innerHTML = "";

    data.data.forEach(item => {
        const row = `<tr>
            <td>${item.id}</td>
            <td>${item.name}</td>
            <td>${item.description}</td>
            <td>${item.price}</td>
        </tr>`;
        tableBody.innerHTML += row;
    });

    const pagination = document.getElementById("pagination");
    pagination.innerHTML = "";
    for (let i = 1; i <= data.total_pages; i++) {
        pagination.innerHTML += `<button onclick="loadItems(${i})">${i}</button>`;
    }
}

document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", () => {
    if (localStorage.getItem("jwt")) {
        document.getElementById("loginSection").style.display = "none";
        document.getElementById("itemSection").style.display = "block";
        loadItems();
    }
});

3️⃣ Updated JS (static/script.js)

javascript
async function saveItem() {
    const token = localStorage.getItem("jwt");
    if (!token) return;

    const id = document.getElementById("itemId").value;
    const name = document.getElementById("itemName").value;
    const description = document.getElementById("itemDesc").value;
    const price = parseFloat(document.getElementById("itemPrice").value);

    const method = id ? "PUT" : "POST";
    const url = id ? `/items/${id}` : `/items`;

    const res = await fetch(url, {
        method: method,
        headers: {
            "Content-Type": "application/json",
            "Authorization": `Bearer ${token}`
        },
        body: JSON.stringify({ name, description, price })
    });

    if (res.ok) {
        resetForm();
        loadItems();
    } else {
        alert("Failed to save item");
    }
}

function editItem(item) {
    document.getElementById("formTitle").textContent = "Edit Item";
    document.getElementById("itemId").value = item.id;
    document.getElementById("itemName").value = item.name;
    document.getElementById("itemDesc").value = item.description;
    document.getElementById("itemPrice").value = item.price;
}

async function deleteItem(id) {
    if (!confirm("Are you sure?")) return;

    const token = localStorage.getItem("jwt");
    const res = await fetch(`/items/${id}`, {
        method: "DELETE",
        headers: { "Authorization": `Bearer ${token}` }
    });

    if (res.ok) {
        loadItems();
    } else {
        alert("Failed to delete item");
    }
}

function resetForm() {
    document.getElementById("formTitle").textContent = "Add New Item";
    document.getElementById("itemId").value = "";
    document.getElementById("itemName").value = "";
    document.getElementById("itemDesc").value = "";
    document.getElementById("itemPrice").value = "";
}

async function loadItems(page = 1) {
    const token = localStorage.getItem("jwt");
    if (!token) return;

    const search = document.getElementById("search").value;
    const sort = document.getElementById("sort").value;
    const order = document.getElementById("order").value;

    const url = `/items?page=${page}&limit=5&search=${search}&sort=${sort}&order=${order}`;

    const res = await fetch(url, {
        headers: { "Authorization": `Bearer ${token}` }
    });

    if (res.status === 401) {
        localStorage.removeItem("jwt");
        location.reload();
        return;
    }

    const data = await res.json();
    const tableBody = document.getElementById("itemTable");
    tableBody.innerHTML = "";

    data.data.forEach(item => {
        const row = `<tr>
            <td>${item.id}</td>
            <td>${item.name}</td>
            <td>${item.description}</td>
            <td>${item.price}</td>
            <td>
                <button onclick='editItem(${JSON.stringify(item)})'>Edit</button>
                <button onclick="deleteItem(${item.id})">Delete</button>
            </td>
        </tr>`;
        tableBody.innerHTML += row;
    });

    const pagination = document.getElementById("pagination");
    pagination.innerHTML = "";
    for (let i = 1; i <= data.total_pages; i++) {
        pagination.innerHTML += `<button onclick="loadItems(${i})">${i}</button>`;
    }
}

Alright — Lesson 17: File Upload & Download in Flask
We’re now adding the ability to upload and download files securely from our Flask app.

📍 Goal of Lesson 17

  • Upload files from the client to the server

  • Restrict allowed file types

  • Serve/download uploaded files

  • Avoid security issues like path traversal

1️⃣ Setup Upload Folder & Config

Add this in your app.py:

python
import os
from flask import Flask, request, send_from_directory
from flask_jwt_extended import jwt_required

UPLOAD_FOLDER = 'uploads'
ALLOWED_EXTENSIONS = {'png', 'jpg', 'jpeg', 'gif', 'pdf', 'txt'}

os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)

app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'] = UPLOAD_FOLDER

2️⃣ Helper Function

python
def allowed_file(filename):
    return '.' in filename and \
           filename.rsplit('.', 1)[1].lower() in ALLOWED_EXTENSIONS

3️⃣ Upload Endpoint

python
@app.route('/upload', methods=['POST'])
@jwt_required()
def upload_file():
    if 'file' not in request.files:
        return {'msg': 'No file part'}, 400

    file = request.files['file']
    if file.filename == '':
        return {'msg': 'No selected file'}, 400

    if file and allowed_file(file.filename):
        filename = os.path.basename(file.filename)  # Prevent path traversal
        save_path = os.path.join(app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'], filename)
        file.save(save_path)
        return {'msg': 'File uploaded', 'filename': filename}, 201

    return {'msg': 'File type not allowed'}, 400

4️⃣ Download Endpoint

python
@app.route('/download/<filename>', methods=['GET'])
@jwt_required()
def download_file(filename):
    safe_filename = os.path.basename(filename)  # Prevent directory traversal
    return send_from_directory(app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'], safe_filename, as_attachment=True)

5️⃣ Test Upload

bash
curl -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer <TOKEN>" \
  -F "file=@example.txt" \
  http://127.0.0.1:5000/upload

6️⃣ Test Download

bash
curl -X GET -H "Authorization: Bearer <TOKEN>" \
  http://127.0.0.1:5000/download/example.txt --output downloaded.txt

📌 Key Points Learned

  • request.files handles file uploads in Flask

  • Security: Always sanitize file names with os.path.basename()

  • Limit allowed file types with a whitelist

  • send_from_directory is the safe way to serve files from disk

  • Use JWT authentication to protect file access

Alright — Lesson 18: File Management UI with Flask + CORS
Now that we can upload & download files via API, we’ll build a browser-based UI so users can:

  • Upload files from a form

  • List uploaded files

  • Download files by clicking

  • (Optional) Preview images directly

1️⃣ Flask API — List Files

Add a list files endpoint in app.py:

python
import os
from flask import jsonify

@app.route('/files', methods=['GET'])
@jwt_required()
def list_files():
    files = os.listdir(app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'])
    return jsonify(files)

2️⃣ Frontend HTML

Save as templates/file_manager.html:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
    <title>Flask File Manager</title>
</head>
<body>
    <h1>File Manager</h1>

    <!-- Upload Form -->
    <form id="uploadForm">
        <input type="file" name="file" required>
        <button type="submit">Upload</button>
    </form>

    <h2>Files</h2>
    <ul id="fileList"></ul>

    <script>
        const token = localStorage.getItem('jwt'); // Store JWT after login

        // Fetch and display files
        function loadFiles() {
            fetch('http://127.0.0.1:5000/files', {
                headers: { Authorization: `Bearer ${token}` }
            })
            .then(res => res.json())
            .then(files => {
                const list = document.getElementById('fileList');
                list.innerHTML = '';
                files.forEach(file => {
                    const li = document.createElement('li');
                    li.innerHTML = `
                        ${file} 
                        <a href="http://127.0.0.1:5000/download/${file}" target="_blank">Download</a>
                    `;
                    list.appendChild(li);
                });
            });
        }

        // Upload file
        document.getElementById('uploadForm').addEventListener('submit', e => {
            e.preventDefault();
            const formData = new FormData(e.target);
            fetch('http://127.0.0.1:5000/upload', {
                method: 'POST',
                headers: { Authorization: `Bearer ${token}` },
                body: formData
            })
            .then(res => res.json())
            .then(() => loadFiles());
        });

        loadFiles();
    </script>
</body>
</html>

3️⃣ Serve the HTML in Flask

python
from flask import render_template

@app.route('/file-manager')
def file_manager():
    return render_template('file_manager.html')

  • /upload → Accepts file upload via FormData

  • /download/<filename> → Downloads a file

  • The frontend automatically fetches file list on load and refreshes after upload

📌 Key Learnings

  • Used fetch with FormData for uploads

  • Dynamically populated a list of files from API data

  • JWT authentication included via Authorization: Bearer header

Alright — Lesson 19: File Manager — Delete, Rename & Preview
Now we’ll make the file manager interactive so users can:

  • Delete files

  • Rename files

  • Preview images without downloading

1️⃣ Flask API — Delete File

python
@app.route('/delete/<filename>', methods=['DELETE'])
@jwt_required()
def delete_file(filename):
    filepath = os.path.join(app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'], filename)
    if os.path.exists(filepath):
        os.remove(filepath)
        return jsonify({"msg": "File deleted"}), 200
    return jsonify({"msg": "File not found"}), 404

2️⃣ Flask API — Rename File

python
@app.route('/rename', methods=['POST'])
@jwt_required()
def rename_file():
    data = request.json
    old_name = data.get('old_name')
    new_name = data.get('new_name')

    if not old_name or not new_name:
        return jsonify({"msg": "Invalid request"}), 400

    old_path = os.path.join(app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'], old_name)
    new_path = os.path.join(app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'], new_name)

    if os.path.exists(old_path):
        os.rename(old_path, new_path)
        return jsonify({"msg": "File renamed"}), 200
    return jsonify({"msg": "File not found"}), 404

3️⃣ Frontend — Update file_manager.html

Add delete, rename, and preview options in the list rendering:

javascript
files.forEach(file => {
    const li = document.createElement('li');
    const fileUrl = `http://127.0.0.1:5000/download/${file}`;

    li.innerHTML = `
        ${file} 
        <a href="${fileUrl}" target="_blank">Download</a>
        <button onclick="deleteFile('${file}')">Delete</button>
        <button onclick="renameFilePrompt('${file}')">Rename</button>
        ${/\.(jpg|jpeg|png|gif)$/i.test(file) 
            ? `<img src="${fileUrl}" alt="${file}" style="max-height:50px;cursor:pointer" onclick="previewImage('${fileUrl}')">`
            : ''}
    `;
    list.appendChild(li);
});

4️⃣ Add JavaScript Functions

javascript
function deleteFile(filename) {
    fetch(`http://127.0.0.1:5000/delete/${filename}`, {
        method: 'DELETE',
        headers: { Authorization: `Bearer ${token}` }
    })
    .then(() => loadFiles());
}

function renameFilePrompt(oldName) {
    const newName = prompt("Enter new file name:", oldName);
    if (!newName || newName === oldName) return;
    fetch(`http://127.0.0.1:5000/rename`, {
        method: 'POST',
        headers: { 
            Authorization: `Bearer ${token}`,
            'Content-Type': 'application/json'
        },
        body: JSON.stringify({ old_name: oldName, new_name: newName })
    })
    .then(() => loadFiles());
}

function previewImage(url) {
    const win = window.open();
    win.document.write(`<img src="${url}" style="max-width:100%">`);
}

5️⃣ How It Works

  • Delete button → Sends DELETE request to /delete/<filename>

  • Rename button → Prompts user, then sends POST request to /rename

  • Preview image → Opens image in a new tab or window for quick viewing

📌 Key Learnings

  • Integrated DELETE and POST (JSON) requests with fetch

  • Used regex to detect images and show inline thumbnails

  • Learned frontend-backend coordination for file management

  • Added UX enhancements with prompt dialogs and image previews

Alright — Lesson 20: Searchable & Sortable File Manager
We’ll make the file list searchable (filter by name) and sortable (by name or size) without reloading the page.

1️⃣ Flask API — Send File Size Along with Names

Update /files route so it returns name and size:

python
@app.route('/files', methods=['GET'])
@jwt_required()
def list_files():
    files = []
    for filename in os.listdir(app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER']):
        path = os.path.join(app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'], filename)
        if os.path.isfile(path):
            size = os.path.getsize(path)
            files.append({"name": filename, "size": size})
    return jsonify(files)

2️⃣ Frontend — Search Bar & Sort Buttons

Add above your file list:

html
<input type="text" id="search" placeholder="Search files..." onkeyup="filterFiles()">
<button onclick="sortFiles('name')">Sort by Name</button>
<button onclick="sortFiles('size')">Sort by Size</button>

<ul id="fileList"></ul>

3️⃣ JavaScript — Store & Render Files

javascript
let allFiles = [];
let sortDirection = { name: 1, size: 1 };

function loadFiles() {
    fetch("http://127.0.0.1:5000/files", {
        headers: { Authorization: `Bearer ${token}` }
    })
    .then(res => res.json())
    .then(data => {
        allFiles = data;
        renderFiles(allFiles);
    });
}

function renderFiles(files) {
    const list = document.getElementById('fileList');
    list.innerHTML = '';
    files.forEach(file => {
        const fileUrl = `http://127.0.0.1:5000/download/${file.name}`;
        const li = document.createElement('li');
        li.innerHTML = `
            ${file.name} (${(file.size / 1024).toFixed(1)} KB)
            <a href="${fileUrl}" target="_blank">Download</a>
        `;
        list.appendChild(li);
    });
}

4️⃣ Implement Search Filter

javascript
function filterFiles() {
    const query = document.getElementById('search').value.toLowerCase();
    const filtered = allFiles.filter(file => file.name.toLowerCase().includes(query));
    renderFiles(filtered);
}

5️⃣ Implement Sorting

javascript
function sortFiles(key) {
    sortDirection[key] *= -1; // toggle direction
    const sorted = [...allFiles].sort((a, b) => {
        if (key === 'name') {
            return sortDirection[key] * a.name.localeCompare(b.name);
        }
        return sortDirection[key] * (a.size - b.size);
    });
    renderFiles(sorted);
}

6️⃣ How It Works

  • Search box: Filters allFiles array in real-time

  • Sort buttons: Sort by name or size ascending/descending

  • No extra backend calls — everything is done client-side

📌 Key Learnings

  • Improved backend to send metadata (name + size)

  • Implemented live search and toggle sorting in JS

  • Created a responsive, interactive table-like list

  • Kept state (allFiles) for efficient UI updates

1️⃣ HTML — Drop Zone & Progress UI

    Drag & Drop Files Here

<p id="uploadStatus"></p>

3️⃣ Upload File with Progress

javascript
function uploadFile(file) {
    const formData = new FormData();
    formData.append('file', file);

    const xhr = new XMLHttpRequest();
    xhr.open("POST", "http://127.0.0.1:5000/upload");

    xhr.setRequestHeader("Authorization", `Bearer ${token}`);

    xhr.upload.onprogress = function (e) {
        if (e.lengthComputable) {
            const percent = (e.loaded / e.total) * 100;
            progressBar.value = percent;
            statusText.innerText = `Uploading: ${percent.toFixed(1)}%`;
        }
    };

    xhr.onload = function () {
        if (xhr.status === 200) {
            statusText.innerText = "✅ Upload complete!";
            loadFiles(); // Refresh file list
        } else {
            statusText.innerText = "❌ Upload failed.";
        }
    };

    xhr.send(formData);
}

We already have:

        return jsonify({"error": "No file uploaded"}), 400

    return jsonify({"message": "File uploaded successfully"})

2️⃣ JavaScript — Validate & Preview

javascript
const dropZone = document.getElementById('dropZone');
const previewContainer = document.getElementById('previewContainer');
const uploadList = document.getElementById('uploadList');

dropZone.addEventListener('dragover', (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    dropZone.style.background = '#eef';
});

dropZone.addEventListener('dragleave', () => {
    dropZone.style.background = '';
});

dropZone.addEventListener('drop', (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    dropZone.style.background = '';
    const files = e.dataTransfer.files;
    if (files.length > 0) {
        for (let file of files) {
            if (validateFile(file)) {
                showPreview(file);
                uploadFile(file);
            }
        }
    }
});

function validateFile(file) {
    const allowedTypes = ["image/jpeg", "image/png", "image/gif", "application/pdf", "text/plain"];
    if (!allowedTypes.includes(file.type)) {
        alert(`File type not allowed: ${file.name}`);
        return false;
    }
    if (file.size > 5 * 1024 * 1024) { // 5 MB limit
        alert(`File too large: ${file.name}`);
        return false;
    }
    return true;
}

function showPreview(file) {
    const preview = document.createElement('div');
    preview.style.border = "1px solid #ccc";
    preview.style.padding = "5px";
    preview.style.textAlign = "center";
    preview.style.width = "100px";

    if (file.type.startsWith("image/")) {
        const img = document.createElement('img');
        img.src = URL.createObjectURL(file);
        img.style.width = "100%";
        img.onload = () => URL.revokeObjectURL(img.src);
        preview.appendChild(img);
    } else {
        preview.innerHTML = `<p>📄 ${file.name}</p>`;
    }
    previewContainer.appendChild(preview);
}
