Alright — Lesson 24: Cancel Upload (Abort Controller)
Now we’ll make our file uploader capable of cancelling uploads mid-way — super useful for large files or when a user changes their mind.

1️⃣ HTML — Add Cancel Button for Each File

We’ll update the preview to include a cancel button next to each file in progress.

html
<div id="dropZone" style="border: 2px dashed #888; padding: 20px; text-align: center;">
    Drag & Drop Files Here
</div>
<br>
<div id="previewContainer" style="display:flex; flex-wrap:wrap; gap:10px;"></div>
<div id="uploadList"></div>

2️⃣ JavaScript — Track Uploads and Allow Abort

We’ll use AbortController to stop the fetch() request when cancel is clicked.

javascript
const dropZone = document.getElementById('dropZone');
const previewContainer = document.getElementById('previewContainer');
const uploadList = document.getElementById('uploadList');
const uploads = {}; // Store active uploads { fileName: {controller, element} }

dropZone.addEventListener('dragover', (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    dropZone.style.background = '#eef';
});

dropZone.addEventListener('dragleave', () => {
    dropZone.style.background = '';
});

dropZone.addEventListener('drop', (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    dropZone.style.background = '';
    const files = e.dataTransfer.files;
    for (let file of files) {
        if (validateFile(file)) {
            showPreview(file);
            startUpload(file);
        }
    }
});

function validateFile(file) {
    const allowedTypes = ["image/jpeg", "image/png", "application/pdf", "text/plain"];
    if (!allowedTypes.includes(file.type)) {
        alert(`❌ File type not allowed: ${file.name}`);
        return false;
    }
    if (file.size > 5 * 1024 * 1024) {
        alert(`❌ File too large: ${file.name}`);
        return false;
    }
    return true;
}

function showPreview(file) {
    const container = document.createElement('div');
    container.style.border = "1px solid #ccc";
    container.style.padding = "5px";
    container.style.width = "120px";
    container.style.textAlign = "center";
    container.style.position = "relative";

    const cancelBtn = document.createElement('button');
    cancelBtn.innerHTML = "❌";
    cancelBtn.style.position = "absolute";
    cancelBtn.style.top = "5px";
    cancelBtn.style.right = "5px";
    cancelBtn.style.cursor = "pointer";

    cancelBtn.addEventListener('click', () => {
        if (uploads[file.name]) {
            uploads[file.name].controller.abort();
            container.style.opacity = "0.5";
            uploads[file.name].status.textContent = "Cancelled";
        }
    });

    if (file.type.startsWith("image/")) {
        const img = document.createElement('img');
        img.src = URL.createObjectURL(file);
        img.style.width = "100%";
        img.onload = () => URL.revokeObjectURL(img.src);
        container.appendChild(img);
    } else {
        container.innerHTML = `<p>📄 ${file.name}</p>`;
    }

    const status = document.createElement('p');
    status.textContent = "Uploading...";
    status.style.fontSize = "12px";

    container.appendChild(cancelBtn);
    container.appendChild(status);
    previewContainer.appendChild(container);

    uploads[file.name] = { status, container }; // Save reference
}

function startUpload(file) {
    const formData = new FormData();
    formData.append('file', file);

    const controller = new AbortController();
    uploads[file.name].controller = controller;

    fetch("/upload", {
        method: "POST",
        body: formData,
        signal: controller.signal
    })
    .then(res => res.json())
    .then(data => {
        uploads[file.name].status.textContent = "✅ Uploaded";
    })
    .catch(err => {
        if (err.name === "AbortError") {
            console.log(`Upload cancelled: ${file.name}`);
        } else {
            uploads[file.name].status.textContent = "❌ Failed";
        }
    });
}

3️⃣ Flask Backend — No Change Needed

This still works with our /upload route from Lesson 22/23.

4️⃣ Key Learnings

  • AbortController stops fetch() without touching the server logic.

  • Keeping a map of active uploads lets you cancel specific files.

  • The UI updates instantly when cancelled (optimistic feedback).

Alright — Lesson 25: Resumable File Uploads (Chunked Uploads)
Now we’ll make uploads pauseable and resumable, perfect for big files or flaky internet connections.

1️⃣ Why Chunked Uploads?

Instead of sending the whole file at once, we:

  • Split the file into small parts (chunks, e.g., 1 MB each).

  • Upload each chunk separately.

  • Server stores chunks until all are received.

  • If connection drops, we resume from the last uploaded chunk.

2️⃣ HTML — Simple Drop Zone

html
<div id="dropZone" style="border: 2px dashed #888; padding: 20px; text-align: center;">
    Drag & Drop Large Files Here
</div>
<div id="progressContainer"></div>

3️⃣ JavaScript — Chunked Upload Logic

javascript
const dropZone = document.getElementById("dropZone");
const progressContainer = document.getElementById("progressContainer");
const CHUNK_SIZE = 1024 * 1024; // 1 MB

dropZone.addEventListener("dragover", (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    dropZone.style.background = "#eef";
});

dropZone.addEventListener("dragleave", () => {
    dropZone.style.background = "";
});

dropZone.addEventListener("drop", (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    dropZone.style.background = "";
    const files = e.dataTransfer.files;
    for (let file of files) {
        uploadFileInChunks(file);
    }
});

async function uploadFileInChunks(file) {
    const fileId = Date.now() + "_" + file.name;
    let start = 0;
    let chunkIndex = 0;

    const progressBar = document.createElement("progress");
    progressBar.max = file.size;
    progressBar.value = 0;
    progressContainer.appendChild(progressBar);

    while (start < file.size) {
        const chunk = file.slice(start, start + CHUNK_SIZE);
        const formData = new FormData();
        formData.append("file", chunk);
        formData.append("file_id", fileId);
        formData.append("chunk_index", chunkIndex);
        formData.append("total_chunks", Math.ceil(file.size / CHUNK_SIZE));
        formData.append("file_name", file.name);

        try {
            await fetch("/upload_chunk", { method: "POST", body: formData });
        } catch (err) {
            alert("Upload failed — you can retry later.");
            return;
        }

        start += CHUNK_SIZE;
        chunkIndex++;
        progressBar.value = start;
    }

    // Tell server to finalize file
    await fetch(`/finalize_upload?file_id=${fileId}`, { method: "POST" });
    alert(`${file.name} uploaded successfully!`);
}

4️⃣ Flask Backend — Chunked Upload Handling

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
import os, shutil

app = Flask(__name__)
UPLOAD_TEMP = "temp_chunks"
UPLOAD_FINAL = "uploaded_files"
os.makedirs(UPLOAD_TEMP, exist_ok=True)
os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FINAL, exist_ok=True)

@app.route("/upload_chunk", methods=["POST"])
def upload_chunk():
    file = request.files["file"]
    file_id = request.form["file_id"]
    chunk_index = request.form["chunk_index"]

    folder = os.path.join(UPLOAD_TEMP, file_id)
    os.makedirs(folder, exist_ok=True)
    file.save(os.path.join(folder, f"chunk_{chunk_index}"))
    return jsonify({"status": "chunk received"})

@app.route("/finalize_upload", methods=["POST"])
def finalize_upload():
    file_id = request.args.get("file_id")
    folder = os.path.join(UPLOAD_TEMP, file_id)

    # Read file name from first chunk's meta
    # Here we store file_name in a separate file
    chunks = sorted(os.listdir(folder), key=lambda x: int(x.split("_")[1]))
    final_path = os.path.join(UPLOAD_FINAL, file_id.split("_", 1)[1])

    with open(final_path, "wb") as final_file:
        for chunk in chunks:
            with open(os.path.join(folder, chunk), "rb") as c:
                shutil.copyfileobj(c, final_file)

    shutil.rmtree(folder)
    return jsonify({"status": "upload complete"})

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True, port=5000)

5️⃣ Key Learnings

  • Chunk size affects upload performance; too small = too many requests, too big = large retry cost.

  • Upload progress can be tracked per chunk.

  • If an upload fails midway, we can resume from the last saved chunk without re-sending the entire file.

  • This approach is friendly for large uploads (e.g., > 2GB) without overloading memory.

Alright — Lesson 26: Pause & Resume Chunked Uploads with LocalStorage
Now we’ll make our big-file uploads even smarter — you can pause, refresh the page, and resume later without losing progress.

1️⃣ What We’re Adding

In Lesson 25, if you refreshed the page mid-upload, you had to restart.
Now we will:

  • Store uploaded chunk info in localStorage.

  • Add Pause / Resume buttons.

  • Resume from the last successfully uploaded chunk.

2️⃣ HTML — With Control Buttons

html
<div id="dropZone" style="border: 2px dashed #888; padding: 20px; text-align: center;">
    Drag & Drop Large Files Here
</div>
<div id="progressContainer"></div>

3️⃣ JavaScript — Pause & Resume Logic

javascript
const CHUNK_SIZE = 1024 * 1024; // 1MB
const uploads = {};

document.getElementById("dropZone").addEventListener("dragover", (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    e.currentTarget.style.background = "#eef";
});

document.getElementById("dropZone").addEventListener("dragleave", (e) => {
    e.currentTarget.style.background = "";
});

document.getElementById("dropZone").addEventListener("drop", (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    e.currentTarget.style.background = "";
    for (let file of e.dataTransfer.files) {
        startUpload(file);
    }
});

function startUpload(file) {
    const fileId = Date.now() + "_" + file.name;
    const savedProgress = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem(fileId)) || { uploadedChunks: 0 };
    uploads[fileId] = { file, fileId, uploadedChunks: savedProgress.uploadedChunks, paused: false };

    const container = document.createElement("div");
    const progressBar = document.createElement("progress");
    const pauseBtn = document.createElement("button");
    const resumeBtn = document.createElement("button");

    progressBar.max = file.size;
    progressBar.value = savedProgress.uploadedChunks * CHUNK_SIZE;

    pauseBtn.textContent = "Pause";
    resumeBtn.textContent = "Resume";
    resumeBtn.disabled = true;

    pauseBtn.onclick = () => {
        uploads[fileId].paused = true;
        pauseBtn.disabled = true;
        resumeBtn.disabled = false;
    };
    resumeBtn.onclick = () => {
        uploads[fileId].paused = false;
        pauseBtn.disabled = false;
        resumeBtn.disabled = true;
        uploadChunks(fileId, progressBar);
    };

    container.appendChild(document.createTextNode(file.name + " "));
    container.appendChild(progressBar);
    container.appendChild(pauseBtn);
    container.appendChild(resumeBtn);
    document.getElementById("progressContainer").appendChild(container);

    uploadChunks(fileId, progressBar);
}

async function uploadChunks(fileId, progressBar) {
    const upload = uploads[fileId];
    let { file, uploadedChunks } = upload;

    while (uploadedChunks * CHUNK_SIZE < file.size) {
        if (upload.paused) return;

        const start = uploadedChunks * CHUNK_SIZE;
        const chunk = file.slice(start, start + CHUNK_SIZE);
        const formData = new FormData();
        formData.append("file", chunk);
        formData.append("file_id", fileId);
        formData.append("chunk_index", uploadedChunks);
        formData.append("total_chunks", Math.ceil(file.size / CHUNK_SIZE));
        formData.append("file_name", file.name);

        try {
            await fetch("/upload_chunk", { method: "POST", body: formData });
        } catch (err) {
            alert("Upload failed — you can resume later.");
            return;
        }

        uploadedChunks++;
        uploads[fileId].uploadedChunks = uploadedChunks;
        localStorage.setItem(fileId, JSON.stringify({ uploadedChunks }));
        progressBar.value = uploadedChunks * CHUNK_SIZE;
    }

    await fetch(`/finalize_upload?file_id=${fileId}`, { method: "POST" });
    localStorage.removeItem(fileId);
    alert(`${file.name} uploaded successfully!`);
}

4️⃣ Flask Backend (Same as Lesson 25)

We don’t change the backend — our /upload_chunk and /finalize_upload routes still work perfectly.

5️⃣ Key Improvements

  • Pause & Resume without re-uploading completed chunks.

  • localStorage stores chunk progress per file.

  • Handles page refresh without losing progress.

  • Still works for large files without memory issues.

Alright — Lesson 27: Upload Verification with Checksum (MD5/SHA256)
Now we’ll make sure that what we send is exactly what the server stores by calculating a hash of the file before upload and verifying it on the server after finalization.

1️⃣ Why This Matters

  • Network issues or disk errors can corrupt uploads.

  • If we just trust the assembled file, we might save bad data.

  • A checksum (hash) lets us guarantee integrity.

2️⃣ How We’ll Do It

  1. Before uploading, calculate the file’s SHA256 in the browser (Web Crypto API).

  2. Send the hash in the /finalize_upload request.

  3. On the server, recalculate SHA256 of the assembled file.

  4. Compare — if different, reject and tell the client to retry.

3️⃣ JavaScript — Adding Hash Calculation

javascript
async function calculateSHA256(file) {
    const buffer = await file.arrayBuffer();
    const hashBuffer = await crypto.subtle.digest("SHA-256", buffer);
    const hashArray = Array.from(new Uint8Array(hashBuffer));
    return hashArray.map(b => b.toString(16).padStart(2, "0")).join("");
}

async function uploadChunks(fileId, progressBar) {
    const upload = uploads[fileId];
    let { file, uploadedChunks } = upload;

    while (uploadedChunks * CHUNK_SIZE < file.size) {
        if (upload.paused) return;

        const start = uploadedChunks * CHUNK_SIZE;
        const chunk = file.slice(start, start + CHUNK_SIZE);
        const formData = new FormData();
        formData.append("file", chunk);
        formData.append("file_id", fileId);
        formData.append("chunk_index", uploadedChunks);
        formData.append("total_chunks", Math.ceil(file.size / CHUNK_SIZE));
        formData.append("file_name", file.name);

        try {
            await fetch("/upload_chunk", { method: "POST", body: formData });
        } catch (err) {
            alert("Upload failed — you can resume later.");
            return;
        }

        uploadedChunks++;
        uploads[fileId].uploadedChunks = uploadedChunks;
        localStorage.setItem(fileId, JSON.stringify({ uploadedChunks }));
        progressBar.value = uploadedChunks * CHUNK_SIZE;
    }

    // Calculate SHA256 before finalizing
    const fileHash = await calculateSHA256(file);

    const finalizeData = new FormData();
    finalizeData.append("file_id", fileId);
    finalizeData.append("expected_hash", fileHash);

    const response = await fetch(`/finalize_upload`, { method: "POST", body: finalizeData });
    const result = await response.json();

    if (result.success) {
        localStorage.removeItem(fileId);
        alert(`${file.name} uploaded successfully and verified!`);
    } else {
        alert(`${file.name} failed verification! Please retry.`);
    }
}

4️⃣ Flask Backend — Verifying Hash

python
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
import os, hashlib

UPLOAD_FOLDER = "uploads"
CHUNKS_FOLDER = "chunks"

app = Flask(__name__)

os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)
os.makedirs(CHUNKS_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)

@app.route("/upload_chunk", methods=["POST"])
def upload_chunk():
    file = request.files["file"]
    file_id = request.form["file_id"]
    chunk_index = request.form["chunk_index"]

    chunk_dir = os.path.join(CHUNKS_FOLDER, file_id)
    os.makedirs(chunk_dir, exist_ok=True)

    chunk_path = os.path.join(chunk_dir, f"{chunk_index}.part")
    file.save(chunk_path)
    return "OK"

@app.route("/finalize_upload", methods=["POST"])
def finalize_upload():
    file_id = request.form["file_id"]
    expected_hash = request.form["expected_hash"]
    chunk_dir = os.path.join(CHUNKS_FOLDER, file_id)

    final_path = os.path.join(UPLOAD_FOLDER, f"{file_id}.bin")

    with open(final_path, "wb") as final_file:
        chunk_files = sorted(os.listdir(chunk_dir), key=lambda x: int(x.split(".")[0]))
        for chunk_name in chunk_files:
            with open(os.path.join(chunk_dir, chunk_name), "rb") as chunk_file:
                final_file.write(chunk_file.read())

    # Calculate SHA256 of assembled file
    sha256_hash = hashlib.sha256()
    with open(final_path, "rb") as f:
        for byte_block in iter(lambda: f.read(4096), b""):
            sha256_hash.update(byte_block)
    actual_hash = sha256_hash.hexdigest()

    if actual_hash != expected_hash:
        os.remove(final_path)  # Remove corrupted file
        return jsonify({"success": False, "error": "Hash mismatch"})

    # Cleanup chunks
    for chunk_name in os.listdir(chunk_dir):
        os.remove(os.path.join(chunk_dir, chunk_name))
    os.rmdir(chunk_dir)

    return jsonify({"success": True})

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

5️⃣ Key Benefits

  • Ensures file integrity after upload.

  • Catches network/disk errors early.

  • Easy to extend for MD5 or other algorithms.

Alright — Lesson 28: Real-Time Upload Progress with WebSockets
Now we’ll remove the need for the browser to constantly check the upload status by letting the server push updates directly to the client in real time.

1️⃣ Why Use WebSockets?

  • In previous lessons, progress was tracked on the client only.

  • If the backend needs to report actual processing status (e.g., virus scanning, thumbnail generation), polling wastes bandwidth.

  • WebSockets give instant, two-way communication.

2️⃣ Flow

  1. Client opens a WebSocket connection to /ws.

  2. When a chunk is received, the backend broadcasts the updated progress to that client.

  3. The frontend updates the progress bar instantly.

  4. On finalization, the server sends a "complete" message.

3️⃣ Frontend — Listening for Progress

javascript
function connectWebSocket(fileId, progressBar) {
    const ws = new WebSocket(`ws://localhost:5000/ws?file_id=${fileId}`);

    ws.onmessage = (event) => {
        const data = JSON.parse(event.data);
        if (data.type === "progress") {
            progressBar.value = data.bytes_uploaded;
        } else if (data.type === "complete") {
            progressBar.value = progressBar.max;
            alert(`${data.file_name} uploaded successfully!`);
        }
    };

    ws.onclose = () => console.log("WebSocket closed");
    ws.onerror = (err) => console.error("WebSocket error", err);
}

We call connectWebSocket(fileId, progressBar) before starting chunk uploads.

4️⃣ Flask Backend — WebSocket Integration

We’ll use Flask-Sock for WebSocket support.

python
from flask import Flask, request
from flask_sock import Sock
import os

app = Flask(__name__)
sock = Sock(app)

UPLOAD_FOLDER = "uploads"
CHUNKS_FOLDER = "chunks"
os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)
os.makedirs(CHUNKS_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)

# Store WebSocket connections per file_id
ws_connections = {}

@sock.route("/ws")
def ws_handler(ws):
    file_id = ws.query_string.decode().split("=")[1]
    ws_connections[file_id] = ws
    while True:
        try:
            message = ws.receive()
            if message is None:
                break
        except:
            break
    del ws_connections[file_id]

@app.route("/upload_chunk", methods=["POST"])
def upload_chunk():
    file = request.files["file"]
    file_id = request.form["file_id"]
    chunk_index = int(request.form["chunk_index"])

    chunk_dir = os.path.join(CHUNKS_FOLDER, file_id)
    os.makedirs(chunk_dir, exist_ok=True)

    chunk_path = os.path.join(chunk_dir, f"{chunk_index}.part")
    file.save(chunk_path)

    # Broadcast progress
    if file_id in ws_connections:
        uploaded_bytes = sum(
            os.path.getsize(os.path.join(chunk_dir, f))
            for f in os.listdir(chunk_dir)
        )
        ws_connections[file_id].send({
            "type": "progress",
            "bytes_uploaded": uploaded_bytes
        })

    return "OK"

@app.route("/finalize_upload", methods=["POST"])
def finalize_upload():
    file_id = request.form["file_id"]
    chunk_dir = os.path.join(CHUNKS_FOLDER, file_id)
    final_path = os.path.join(UPLOAD_FOLDER, f"{file_id}.bin")

    with open(final_path, "wb") as final_file:
        for chunk_name in sorted(os.listdir(chunk_dir), key=lambda x: int(x.split(".")[0])):
            with open(os.path.join(chunk_dir, chunk_name), "rb") as chunk_file:
                final_file.write(chunk_file.read())

    # Notify completion
    if file_id in ws_connections:
        ws_connections[file_id].send({
            "type": "complete",
            "file_name": f"{file_id}.bin"
        })

    # Cleanup
    for chunk_name in os.listdir(chunk_dir):
        os.remove(os.path.join(chunk_dir, chunk_name))
    os.rmdir(chunk_dir)

    return "OK"

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

5️⃣ Benefits

  • Zero polling → lighter load on both client & server.

  • Instant updates even if server is doing post-processing.

  • Can easily extend for multi-file upload monitoring.

Alright — Lesson 29: Multi-User, Multi-File Real-Time Upload Tracking
This builds on Lesson 28, but we’ll make the WebSocket system multi-user safe so uploads don’t interfere with each other.

1️⃣ Why This Lesson?

In Lesson 28, we stored WebSocket connections in a single dictionary keyed only by file_id.

  • If two users upload with the same file_id (hash collision or guess), they would see each other’s progress.

  • In real-world apps, you must isolate users and files.

2️⃣ The Upgrade Plan

We will:

  1. Generate a unique session ID for each upload.

  2. Key our ws_connections by (session_id, file_id).

  3. Only broadcast progress to the exact client that owns that upload.

  4. Support multiple simultaneous uploads per user.

3️⃣ Updated Frontend

We generate a sessionId in the browser and send it to both the WebSocket and chunk upload API.

javascript
const sessionId = crypto.randomUUID();

function connectWebSocket(fileId, progressBar) {
    const ws = new WebSocket(`ws://localhost:5000/ws?session_id=${sessionId}&file_id=${fileId}`);

    ws.onmessage = (event) => {
        const data = JSON.parse(event.data);
        if (data.type === "progress") {
            progressBar.value = data.bytes_uploaded;
        } else if (data.type === "complete") {
            progressBar.value = progressBar.max;
            alert(`${data.file_name} uploaded successfully!`);
        }
    };
}

When uploading chunks:

javascript
formData.append("session_id", sessionId);

4️⃣ Updated Backend

python
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
from flask_sock import Sock
import os, json

app = Flask(__name__)
sock = Sock(app)

UPLOAD_FOLDER = "uploads"
CHUNKS_FOLDER = "chunks"
os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)
os.makedirs(CHUNKS_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)

# Dictionary: {(session_id, file_id): ws_connection}
ws_connections = {}

@sock.route("/ws")
def ws_handler(ws):
    query_params = dict(q.split("=") for q in ws.query_string.decode().split("&"))
    session_id = query_params["session_id"]
    file_id = query_params["file_id"]

    ws_connections[(session_id, file_id)] = ws

    while True:
        try:
            message = ws.receive()
            if message is None:
                break
        except:
            break

    del ws_connections[(session_id, file_id)]

@app.route("/upload_chunk", methods=["POST"])
def upload_chunk():
    file = request.files["file"]
    file_id = request.form["file_id"]
    session_id = request.form["session_id"]
    chunk_index = int(request.form["chunk_index"])

    chunk_dir = os.path.join(CHUNKS_FOLDER, session_id, file_id)
    os.makedirs(chunk_dir, exist_ok=True)

    chunk_path = os.path.join(chunk_dir, f"{chunk_index}.part")
    file.save(chunk_path)

    # Calculate progress
    uploaded_bytes = sum(
        os.path.getsize(os.path.join(chunk_dir, f))
        for f in os.listdir(chunk_dir)
    )

    conn_key = (session_id, file_id)
    if conn_key in ws_connections:
        ws_connections[conn_key].send(json.dumps({
            "type": "progress",
            "bytes_uploaded": uploaded_bytes
        }))

    return jsonify({"status": "ok"})

@app.route("/finalize_upload", methods=["POST"])
def finalize_upload():
    file_id = request.form["file_id"]
    session_id = request.form["session_id"]

    chunk_dir = os.path.join(CHUNKS_FOLDER, session_id, file_id)
    final_dir = os.path.join(UPLOAD_FOLDER, session_id)
    os.makedirs(final_dir, exist_ok=True)
    final_path = os.path.join(final_dir, f"{file_id}.bin")

    with open(final_path, "wb") as final_file:
        for chunk_name in sorted(os.listdir(chunk_dir), key=lambda x: int(x.split(".")[0])):
            with open(os.path.join(chunk_dir, chunk_name), "rb") as chunk_file:
                final_file.write(chunk_file.read())

    conn_key = (session_id, file_id)
    if conn_key in ws_connections:
        ws_connections[conn_key].send(json.dumps({
            "type": "complete",
            "file_name": f"{file_id}.bin"
        }))

    # Cleanup chunks
    for chunk_name in os.listdir(chunk_dir):
        os.remove(os.path.join(chunk_dir, chunk_name))
    os.rmdir(chunk_dir)

    return jsonify({"status": "complete"})

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

5️⃣ Benefits

  • Multiple users can upload without interfering with each other.

  • A single user can upload multiple files at once.

  • Secure separation by (session_id, file_id) pairing.

  • Easily extendable to authentication-based session_id.

Alright — Lesson 30: Secure Authenticated Resumable Uploads
Now we take the multi-user, multi-file real-time uploads from Lesson 29 and make them:

  1. Secure – Only authenticated users can upload.

  2. Resumable – Upload can survive browser reloads or network drops.

1️⃣ Problem in Lesson 29

  • If someone guesses a session_id & file_id, they can:

    • Inject fake progress messages

    • Hijack uploads

  • If browser refreshes, upload restarts from scratch.

2️⃣ Solution Overview

We add:

  • JWT-based authentication for every API call & WebSocket.

  • Persistent chunk storage with a manifest file.

  • Upload resumes by checking existing chunks before re-uploading.

3️⃣ Backend Changes

Authentication with JWT

python
import jwt, datetime

SECRET_KEY = "supersecret"

def create_jwt(user_id):
    return jwt.encode({
        "user_id": user_id,
        "exp": datetime.datetime.utcnow() + datetime.timedelta(hours=1)
    }, SECRET_KEY, algorithm="HS256")

def verify_jwt(token):
    try:
        return jwt.decode(token, SECRET_KEY, algorithms=["HS256"])
    except:
        return None

Protected WebSocket

python
@sock.route("/ws")
def ws_handler(ws):
    query_params = dict(q.split("=") for q in ws.query_string.decode().split("&"))
    token = query_params.get("token")
    auth_data = verify_jwt(token)

    if not auth_data:
        ws.send(json.dumps({"type": "error", "message": "Unauthorized"}))
        ws.close()
        return

    session_id = auth_data["user_id"]  # use user_id as session scope
    file_id = query_params["file_id"]

    ws_connections[(session_id, file_id)] = ws

    while True:
        try:
            if ws.receive() is None:
                break
        except:
            break

    del ws_connections[(session_id, file_id)]

Resumable Upload

We maintain a .manifest file per upload to track chunks:

python
@app.route("/upload_chunk", methods=["POST"])
def upload_chunk():
    token = request.form["token"]
    auth_data = verify_jwt(token)
    if not auth_data:
        return jsonify({"error": "Unauthorized"}), 401

    session_id = auth_data["user_id"]
    file_id = request.form["file_id"]
    chunk_index = int(request.form["chunk_index"])

    chunk_dir = os.path.join(CHUNKS_FOLDER, session_id, file_id)
    os.makedirs(chunk_dir, exist_ok=True)

    chunk_path = os.path.join(chunk_dir, f"{chunk_index}.part")
    request.files["file"].save(chunk_path)

    # Update manifest
    manifest_path = os.path.join(chunk_dir, "manifest.json")
    if os.path.exists(manifest_path):
        manifest = json.load(open(manifest_path))
    else:
        manifest = {"uploaded_chunks": []}

    if chunk_index not in manifest["uploaded_chunks"]:
        manifest["uploaded_chunks"].append(chunk_index)
        json.dump(manifest, open(manifest_path, "w"))

    # Send progress
    uploaded_bytes = sum(
        os.path.getsize(os.path.join(chunk_dir, f))
        for f in os.listdir(chunk_dir) if f.endswith(".part")
    )
    conn_key = (session_id, file_id)
    if conn_key in ws_connections:
        ws_connections[conn_key].send(json.dumps({
            "type": "progress",
            "bytes_uploaded": uploaded_bytes
        }))

    return jsonify({"status": "ok"})

Resume Check Endpoint

python
@app.route("/resume_check", methods=["POST"])
def resume_check():
    token = request.form["token"]
    auth_data = verify_jwt(token)
    if not auth_data:
        return jsonify({"error": "Unauthorized"}), 401

    session_id = auth_data["user_id"]
    file_id = request.form["file_id"]

    manifest_path = os.path.join(CHUNKS_FOLDER, session_id, file_id, "manifest.json")
    if os.path.exists(manifest_path):
        manifest = json.load(open(manifest_path))
        return jsonify({"uploaded_chunks": manifest["uploaded_chunks"]})
    else:
        return jsonify({"uploaded_chunks": []})

4️⃣ Frontend Changes

When the page loads:

javascript
const token = localStorage.getItem("jwt_token"); // already logged in

async function resumeUpload(fileId) {
    const formData = new FormData();
    formData.append("token", token);
    formData.append("file_id", fileId);

    let response = await fetch("/resume_check", { method: "POST", body: formData });
    let data = await response.json();
    return data.uploaded_chunks;
}

Before uploading, skip already uploaded chunks:

javascript
let uploadedChunks = await resumeUpload(fileId);
for (let i = 0; i < totalChunks; i++) {
    if (uploadedChunks.includes(i)) continue;
    // upload this chunk
}

  • Resumable uploads survive refreshes, crashes, or network loss.

  • Scalable to multiple users with isolated data.

Alright — Lesson 31: Parallel Chunk Uploads with Real-Time WebSocket Progress
Now we take the resumable, secure upload system from Lesson 30 and make it fast.
Instead of sending chunks sequentially, we’ll upload multiple chunks in parallel while still tracking progress live.

1️⃣ Why Parallel Uploads?

  • Sequential uploads wait for each chunk to finish before starting the next → slower for large files.

  • Parallel uploads send several chunks at once → better network utilization.

  • Works especially well for high-latency or high-bandwidth connections.

2️⃣ Backend Adjustments

No big API changes — the /upload_chunk endpoint already supports chunks being uploaded in any order.
The only requirement:

  • Chunks must be stored with their chunk_index in the manifest.

3️⃣ Frontend Parallel Upload Logic

We’ll upload up to MAX_PARALLEL chunks at once.

javascript
const MAX_PARALLEL = 4; // Number of simultaneous uploads
const token = localStorage.getItem("jwt_token");

async function uploadFileParallel(file, fileId) {
    const chunkSize = 2 * 1024 * 1024; // 2MB
    const totalChunks = Math.ceil(file.size / chunkSize);

    let uploadedChunks = await resumeUpload(fileId); // from Lesson 30
    let currentIndex = 0;

    async function uploadNextChunk() {
        if (currentIndex >= totalChunks) return;
        let i = currentIndex++;
        if (uploadedChunks.includes(i)) {
            await uploadNextChunk();
            return;
        }

        let start = i * chunkSize;
        let end = Math.min(start + chunkSize, file.size);
        let blob = file.slice(start, end);

        let formData = new FormData();
        formData.append("token", token);
        formData.append("file_id", fileId);
        formData.append("chunk_index", i);
        formData.append("file", blob);

        await fetch("/upload_chunk", { method: "POST", body: formData });
        await uploadNextChunk(); // Start another chunk after finishing
    }

    // Kick off parallel uploads
    let workers = [];
    for (let j = 0; j < MAX_PARALLEL; j++) {
        workers.push(uploadNextChunk());
    }

    await Promise.all(workers);
    console.log("All chunks uploaded.");
}

4️⃣ Real-Time Progress with WebSockets

Since /upload_chunk sends a WebSocket progress update for each chunk, the frontend listener from Lesson 29/30 still works.

Example:

javascript
let ws = new WebSocket(`ws://localhost:5000/ws?token=${token}&file_id=${fileId}`);
ws.onmessage = (msg) => {
    let data = JSON.parse(msg.data);
    if (data.type === "progress") {
        updateProgressBar(data.bytes_uploaded);
    }
};

5️⃣ Benefits

✅ Much faster uploads — especially for big files.
✅ Resilient — works with resume from Lesson 30.
✅ Live updates — user always sees progress.
✅ Efficient bandwidth usage — saturates connection.

Nice — Lesson 32: Server-side chunk merging with hash verification (atomic, safe, production-minded).

We’ll finish the resumable + parallel upload pipeline by implementing a robust finalize (merge) step on the server that:

  • Assembles the chunk files in correct order into a single temp file (streamed, not fully in memory).

  • Computes the SHA-256 of the assembled file while writing.

  • Compares it with the client-provided expected_hash.

  • Atomically moves the verified file into the final uploads directory.

  • Uses a file lock to avoid race conditions if finalize is called twice or two processes try to finalize concurrently.

  • Cleans up chunk files / manifests on success; keeps chunks and returns an error on hash-mismatch for retry.

Below are recommended server and client snippets, plus explanation and safety notes.

Project layout (relevant parts)

bash
app/
 ├─ uploads/            # final files (available to download)
 ├─ chunks/             # per-session/per-file chunk dirs
 └─ app.py              # Flask app with endpoints below

Server — Flask endpoints (merge + verify)

Save as app/app.py (or integrate into your existing Flask app). All Python files include the shebang per your preference.

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
Lesson 32: finalize_upload that merges chunks, verifies SHA256, and atomically moves the file.
Assumes chunk upload endpoint stores chunk files as: chunks/<session_id>/<file_id>/<chunk_index>.part
"""

import os
import json
import hashlib
import shutil
import fcntl
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify

BASE_DIR = os.path.abspath(os.path.dirname(__file__))
CHUNKS_ROOT = os.path.join(BASE_DIR, "chunks")
UPLOADS_ROOT = os.path.join(BASE_DIR, "uploads")
os.makedirs(CHUNKS_ROOT, exist_ok=True)
os.makedirs(UPLOADS_ROOT, exist_ok=True)

app = Flask(__name__)

def atomic_write_from_chunks(chunk_dir, dest_tmp_path, total_chunks):
    """
    Stream all chunk files (0..total_chunks-1) into dest_tmp_path.
    Returns SHA256 hex digest of the assembled file.
    """
    sha256 = hashlib.sha256()
    with open(dest_tmp_path, "wb") as out_f:
        # Optionally lock the output file to be extra-safe (not strictly necessary here)
        fcntl.flock(out_f.fileno(), fcntl.LOCK_EX)
        try:
            for i in range(total_chunks):
                chunk_name = f"{i}.part"
                chunk_path = os.path.join(chunk_dir, chunk_name)
                if not os.path.exists(chunk_path):
                    raise FileNotFoundError(f"Missing chunk: {chunk_name}")
                with open(chunk_path, "rb") as cf:
                    # stream copy with hashing
                    while True:
                        data = cf.read(4096)
                        if not data:
                            break
                        out_f.write(data)
                        sha256.update(data)
        finally:
            fcntl.flock(out_f.fileno(), fcntl.LOCK_UN)
    return sha256.hexdigest()

def cleanup_chunk_dir(chunk_dir):
    """Remove all files in chunk_dir and the directory itself."""
    try:
        for name in os.listdir(chunk_dir):
            os.remove(os.path.join(chunk_dir, name))
        os.rmdir(chunk_dir)
    except Exception:
        # best-effort cleanup (log in real app)
        pass

@app.route("/finalize_upload", methods=["POST"])
def finalize_upload():
    """
    Expected form fields (POST):
      - session_id
      - file_id
      - total_chunks (int)
      - file_name (original name; used only for final filename)
      - expected_hash (hex SHA256 from client)

    Behavior:
      1) Verify chunks present count == total_chunks (or manifest check)
      2) Assemble chunks into a temp file (in uploads/.tmp/)
      3) Compute SHA256 while streaming
      4) If match: atomically rename temp -> uploads/<safe_name>
         If mismatch: delete temp, return error (client can retry)
    """
    session_id = request.form.get("session_id")
    file_id = request.form.get("file_id")
    total_chunks = int(request.form.get("total_chunks", 0))
    file_name = request.form.get("file_name", f"{file_id}.bin")
    expected_hash = request.form.get("expected_hash")

    if not (session_id and file_id and total_chunks and expected_hash):
        return jsonify({"success": False, "error": "missing parameters"}), 400

    # path isolation per session -> file_id
    chunk_dir = os.path.join(CHUNKS_ROOT, session_id, file_id)
    if not os.path.isdir(chunk_dir):
        return jsonify({"success": False, "error": "no chunks found"}), 404

    # quick sanity: check how many chunk files exist (best-effort)
    present_chunks = [name for name in os.listdir(chunk_dir) if name.endswith(".part")]
    if len(present_chunks) < total_chunks:
        return jsonify({"success": False, "error": "incomplete upload", "have": len(present_chunks)}), 400

    # ensure final file name is safe
    safe_name = os.path.basename(file_name)
    final_dir = os.path.join(UPLOADS_ROOT, session_id)
    os.makedirs(final_dir, exist_ok=True)
    tmp_dir = os.path.join(final_dir, ".tmp")
    os.makedirs(tmp_dir, exist_ok=True)
    tmp_path = os.path.join(tmp_dir, f"{file_id}.tmp")
    final_path = os.path.join(final_dir, safe_name)

    # Use a lock file to prevent concurrent finalize for same (session_id, file_id)
    lock_path = os.path.join(chunk_dir, ".finalize.lock")
    with open(lock_path, "w+") as lock_f:
        try:
            # Acquire exclusive lock (blocks until acquired)
            fcntl.flock(lock_f.fileno(), fcntl.LOCK_EX)

            # If final file already exists, return success (idempotent)
            if os.path.exists(final_path):
                # cleanup chunk_dir (optional)
                cleanup_chunk_dir(chunk_dir)
                return jsonify({"success": True, "message": "already exists", "path": final_path})

            # Assemble into tmp_path and compute hash
            try:
                actual_hash = atomic_write_from_chunks(chunk_dir, tmp_path, total_chunks)
            except FileNotFoundError as e:
                # missing chunk - abort
                if os.path.exists(tmp_path):
                    os.remove(tmp_path)
                return jsonify({"success": False, "error": str(e)}), 400

            if actual_hash != expected_hash:
                # Hash mismatch: remove tmp and keep chunks for retry
                os.remove(tmp_path)
                return jsonify({"success": False, "error": "hash_mismatch", "actual_hash": actual_hash}), 400

            # Hash matched -> atomically move tmp -> final_path
            os.replace(tmp_path, final_path)  # atomic on same filesystem

            # cleanup chunk dir (best effort)
            cleanup_chunk_dir(chunk_dir)

            return jsonify({"success": True, "path": final_path, "sha256": actual_hash})
        finally:
            try:
                fcntl.flock(lock_f.fileno(), fcntl.LOCK_UN)
            except Exception:
                pass

Notes on server code

  • atomic_write_from_chunks streams chunk files into a temp file while calculating SHA-256. That avoids loading the whole file into memory.

  • We use fcntl.flock to lock the .finalize.lock file so concurrent finalizes for the same file/session don't collide.

  • os.replace() performs an atomic rename on POSIX; replace is safe if source and destination are on same filesystem.

  • We keep chunks if hash mismatch so the client can retry finalize after re-uploading bad chunks. Optionally you can delete chunks after certain retries or TTL cleanup.

Client — After all parallel chunk uploads complete

Client must call /finalize_upload with expected_hash (SHA256 of original file) and total_chunks. Example JS:

javascript
// calculate SHA256 (browser Web Crypto)
async function calculateSHA256Hex(file) {
    const buffer = await file.arrayBuffer();
    const hashBuffer = await crypto.subtle.digest("SHA-256", buffer);
    const hashArray = Array.from(new Uint8Array(hashBuffer));
    return hashArray.map(b => b.toString(16).padStart(2, "0")).join("");
}

// call finalize
async function finalizeUpload(sessionId, fileId, file, totalChunks) {
    const expected_hash = await calculateSHA256Hex(file);
    const form = new FormData();
    form.append("session_id", sessionId);
    form.append("file_id", fileId);
    form.append("file_name", file.name);
    form.append("total_chunks", totalChunks);
    form.append("expected_hash", expected_hash);

    const r = await fetch("/finalize_upload", { method: "POST", body: form });
    const j = await r.json();
    if (r.ok && j.success) {
        console.log("File assembled & verified:", j.path);
    } else {
        console.error("Finalize failed:", j);
        // if hash_mismatch: you can re-upload missing/corrupt chunks and call finalize again
    }
}

Workflow on client:

  1. Split file into chunks and upload chunks in parallel (Lessons 31).

  2. Wait until all chunk uploads respond OK (or skip already-uploaded via resume).

  3. Compute expected_hash (SHA-256) locally.

  4. POST /finalize_upload with session_id, file_id, file_name, total_chunks, expected_hash.

  5. Handle response:

    • success:true → done

    • hash_mismatch or incomplete → re-upload missing/corrupt chunks then finalize again.

Additional production considerations

  • Chunk TTL / Cleanup: schedule a periodic job to remove stale chunk dirs older than N hours.

  • Filesystem & quotas: ensure enough disk space and per-user quota to prevent abuse.

  • Chunk naming and size: use consistent chunk size and index naming (0.part, 1.part, ...).

  • Authentication & Authorization: finalize and upload endpoints should validate JWT and tie session_id to authenticated user for safety. (See Lesson 30.)

  • Integrity after rename: os.replace is atomic but only on same filesystem; ensure tmp_dir and final_dir are same FS.

  • Concurrency: locking via fcntl works for single-host deployments. For multi-host (multiple servers), use Redis locks or DB locks.

  • Virus scanning / post-processing: run asynchronous scanning after finalize; if it fails, quarantine the file and notify user.

  • Chunk corruption: you can compute a per-chunk checksum and verify each chunk on upload for extra safety (optional).

  • Rate-limiting & quotas: protect endpoints with rate-limits (e.g., Flask-Limiter) to avoid DoS.

Quick summary

  • Server-side merge does streamed assembly + SHA-256 verification.

  • Finalization is atomic and locked to avoid races.

  • Client must provide expected_hash and total_chunks after all chunks uploaded.

  • On success, the assembled file is moved into uploads/<session_id>/<safe_name>.

ChatGPT said:

Got it — here’s a single Python file containing:

  • A Flask server with:

    • POST /upload_chunk — receives chunk uploads

    • GET /ws — WebSocket endpoint for live progress updates

    • Auto-merging chunks into the final file when complete

  • A minimal HTML+JS client served by Flask that:

    • Splits the file into chunks

    • Uploads multiple chunks in parallel (MAX_PARALLEL = 4)

    • Shows live progress from the WebSocket

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask, request, send_from_directory, render_template_string
from flask_sock import Sock
import os, json

UPLOAD_FOLDER = "uploads"
CHUNK_FOLDER = "chunks"
os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)
os.makedirs(CHUNK_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)

app = Flask(__name__)
sock = Sock(app)

# Store WebSocket connections for live updates
clients = {}

# Minimal HTML + JS client
HTML_PAGE = """
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<title>Parallel Chunk Upload Test</title>
<style>
  body { font-family: sans-serif; padding: 20px; }
  #progress { width: 100%; background: #ddd; height: 20px; margin-top: 10px; }
  #bar { height: 20px; background: green; width: 0%; }
</style>
</head>
<body>
<h1>Parallel Chunk Upload Test</h1>
<input type="file" id="fileInput" />
<div id="progress"><div id="bar"></div></div>
<p id="status"></p>
<script>
const MAX_PARALLEL = 4;
let ws;

function updateProgressBar(percent) {
    document.getElementById("bar").style.width = percent + "%";
}

async function uploadFileParallel(file, fileId) {
    const chunkSize = 1024 * 1024; // 1MB
    const totalChunks = Math.ceil(file.size / chunkSize);
    let currentIndex = 0;

    async function uploadNextChunk() {
        if (currentIndex >= totalChunks) return;
        let i = currentIndex++;
        let start = i * chunkSize;
        let end = Math.min(start + chunkSize, file.size);
        let blob = file.slice(start, end);

        let formData = new FormData();
        formData.append("file_id", fileId);
        formData.append("chunk_index", i);
        formData.append("total_chunks", totalChunks);
        formData.append("chunk", blob);

        await fetch("/upload_chunk", { method: "POST", body: formData });
        await uploadNextChunk();
    }

    let workers = [];
    for (let j = 0; j < MAX_PARALLEL; j++) {
        workers.push(uploadNextChunk());
    }
    await Promise.all(workers);
    document.getElementById("status").textContent = "Upload complete!";
}

document.getElementById("fileInput").addEventListener("change", async () => {
    let file = document.getElementById("fileInput").files[0];
    let fileId = file.name + "-" + Date.now();

    ws = new WebSocket(`ws://${location.host}/ws?file_id=${encodeURIComponent(fileId)}`);
    ws.onmessage = (msg) => {
        let data = JSON.parse(msg.data);
        if (data.type === "progress") {
            let percent = Math.floor((data.uploaded_bytes / file.size) * 100);
            updateProgressBar(percent);
        }
    };

    uploadFileParallel(file, fileId);
});
</script>
</body>
</html>
"""

@app.route("/")
def index():
    return render_template_string(HTML_PAGE)

@app.route("/upload_chunk", methods=["POST"])
def upload_chunk():
    file_id = request.form["file_id"]
    chunk_index = int(request.form["chunk_index"])
    total_chunks = int(request.form["total_chunks"])
    chunk = request.files["chunk"]

    chunk_dir = os.path.join(CHUNK_FOLDER, file_id)
    os.makedirs(chunk_dir, exist_ok=True)
    chunk_path = os.path.join(chunk_dir, f"{chunk_index}.part")
    chunk.save(chunk_path)

    # Notify progress
    uploaded_bytes = sum(os.path.getsize(os.path.join(chunk_dir, f))
                         for f in os.listdir(chunk_dir))
    if file_id in clients:
        try:
            clients[file_id].send(json.dumps({"type": "progress", "uploaded_bytes": uploaded_bytes}))
        except:
            pass

    # Merge if complete
    if len(os.listdir(chunk_dir)) == total_chunks:
        final_path = os.path.join(UPLOAD_FOLDER, file_id)
        with open(final_path, "wb") as final_file:
            for i in range(total_chunks):
                with open(os.path.join(chunk_dir, f"{i}.part"), "rb") as part:
                    final_file.write(part.read())
        # Cleanup
        for f in os.listdir(chunk_dir):
            os.remove(os.path.join(chunk_dir, f))
        os.rmdir(chunk_dir)

    return "OK"

@sock.route("/ws")
def websocket(ws):
    file_id = ws.scope["query_string"].decode().split("file_id=")[-1]
    clients[file_id] = ws
    try:
        while True:
            ws.receive()  # keep connection open
    except:
        pass
    finally:
        clients.pop(file_id, None)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run("0.0.0.0", 5000, debug=True)

How to run locally

bash
pip install flask flask-sock
python3 parallel_upload_demo.py

Alright — next lesson builds on that parallel chunk upload example by adding resumable uploads so if the connection drops or the browser closes, you can resume from where you left off without re-uploading completed chunks.

Lesson: Resumable Parallel Chunk Uploads

Key Additions

  1. Chunk existence check before upload

    • Client asks /upload_status which chunks are already uploaded.

    • Server replies with list of completed chunk indexes.

  2. Skip already-uploaded chunks

    • Client only uploads missing chunks.

  3. Persistent chunk storage

    • Server keeps partial uploads until the final file is fully assembled.

Updated Single-File Example

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify, render_template_string
from flask_sock import Sock
import os, json

UPLOAD_FOLDER = "uploads"
CHUNK_FOLDER = "chunks"
os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)
os.makedirs(CHUNK_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)

app = Flask(__name__)
sock = Sock(app)
clients = {}  # file_id -> websocket

HTML_PAGE = """
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<title>Resumable Parallel Upload</title>
<style>
  body { font-family: sans-serif; padding: 20px; }
  #progress { width: 100%; background: #ddd; height: 20px; margin-top: 10px; }
  #bar { height: 20px; background: green; width: 0%; }
</style>
</head>
<body>
<h1>Resumable Parallel Chunk Upload Test</h1>
<input type="file" id="fileInput" />
<div id="progress"><div id="bar"></div></div>
<p id="status"></p>
<script>
const MAX_PARALLEL = 4;

function updateProgressBar(percent) {
    document.getElementById("bar").style.width = percent + "%";
}

async function getUploadStatus(fileId) {
    let res = await fetch(`/upload_status?file_id=${encodeURIComponent(fileId)}`);
    return await res.json();
}

async function uploadFileParallel(file, fileId) {
    const chunkSize = 1024 * 1024; // 1MB
    const totalChunks = Math.ceil(file.size / chunkSize);

    let status = await getUploadStatus(fileId);
    let uploadedChunks = new Set(status.uploaded_chunks);

    async function uploadChunk(i) {
        if (uploadedChunks.has(i)) return; // skip
        let start = i * chunkSize;
        let end = Math.min(start + chunkSize, file.size);
        let blob = file.slice(start, end);

        let formData = new FormData();
        formData.append("file_id", fileId);
        formData.append("chunk_index", i);
        formData.append("total_chunks", totalChunks);
        formData.append("chunk", blob);

        await fetch("/upload_chunk", { method: "POST", body: formData });
    }

    let nextIndex = 0;
    async function worker() {
        while (nextIndex < totalChunks) {
            let i = nextIndex++;
            await uploadChunk(i);
        }
    }

    let ws = new WebSocket(`ws://${location.host}/ws?file_id=${encodeURIComponent(fileId)}`);
    ws.onmessage = (msg) => {
        let data = JSON.parse(msg.data);
        if (data.type === "progress") {
            let percent = Math.floor((data.uploaded_bytes / file.size) * 100);
            updateProgressBar(percent);
        }
    };

    let workers = [];
    for (let j = 0; j < MAX_PARALLEL; j++) workers.push(worker());
    await Promise.all(workers);
    document.getElementById("status").textContent = "Upload complete!";
}

document.getElementById("fileInput").addEventListener("change", async () => {
    let file = document.getElementById("fileInput").files[0];
    let fileId = file.name + "-" + file.size; // stable ID for resume
    uploadFileParallel(file, fileId);
});
</script>
</body>
</html>
"""

@app.route("/")
def index():
    return render_template_string(HTML_PAGE)

@app.route("/upload_status")
def upload_status():
    file_id = request.args["file_id"]
    chunk_dir = os.path.join(CHUNK_FOLDER, file_id)
    uploaded_chunks = []
    if os.path.exists(chunk_dir):
        uploaded_chunks = [int(f.split(".")[0]) for f in os.listdir(chunk_dir) if f.endswith(".part")]
    return jsonify({"uploaded_chunks": uploaded_chunks})

@app.route("/upload_chunk", methods=["POST"])
def upload_chunk():
    file_id = request.form["file_id"]
    chunk_index = int(request.form["chunk_index"])
    total_chunks = int(request.form["total_chunks"])
    chunk = request.files["chunk"]

    chunk_dir = os.path.join(CHUNK_FOLDER, file_id)
    os.makedirs(chunk_dir, exist_ok=True)
    chunk_path = os.path.join(chunk_dir, f"{chunk_index}.part")
    chunk.save(chunk_path)

    uploaded_bytes = sum(os.path.getsize(os.path.join(chunk_dir, f))
                         for f in os.listdir(chunk_dir))
    if file_id in clients:
        try:
            clients[file_id].send(json.dumps({"type": "progress", "uploaded_bytes": uploaded_bytes}))
        except:
            pass

    # Merge if complete
    if len(os.listdir(chunk_dir)) == total_chunks:
        final_path = os.path.join(UPLOAD_FOLDER, file_id)
        with open(final_path, "wb") as final_file:
            for i in range(total_chunks):
                with open(os.path.join(chunk_dir, f"{i}.part"), "rb") as part:
                    final_file.write(part.read())
        for f in os.listdir(chunk_dir):
            os.remove(os.path.join(chunk_dir, f))
        os.rmdir(chunk_dir)

    return "OK"

@sock.route("/ws")
def websocket(ws):
    file_id = ws.scope["query_string"].decode().split("file_id=")[-1]
    clients[file_id] = ws
    try:
        while True:
            ws.receive()
    except:
        pass
    finally:
        clients.pop(file_id, None)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run("0.0.0.0", 5000, debug=True)

How it works now

  • Client generates a stable file ID:

    arduino
    file.name + "-" + file.size

    so that if you reload the page, it identifies the same file.

  • Before uploading, the client calls /upload_status to get a list of completed chunks.

  • Missing chunks are uploaded in parallel.

  • WebSocket still updates live progress.

  3. Select a big file → wait until ~50%

  4. Stop the browser tab, reopen the page, select the same file → it resumes instantly.

# Flask Training - Full Lessons (1 to 32)

Below are all lessons from the Flask training program with example code.

## Lesson 1: Your First Flask App

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route("/")
def home():
    return "Hello, Flask!"

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

Run this file and visit http://127.0.0.1:5000.

Lesson 2: Routing in Flask

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route("/")
def home():
    return "Home Page"

@app.route("/about")
def about():
    return "About Page"

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

Lesson 3: Templates and Jinja2

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask, render_template

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route("/")
def home():
    return render_template("index.html", name="Kirubakaran")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

html

Lesson 4: Static Files

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask, send_from_directory

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route("/static/<path:filename>")
def static_files(filename):
    return send_from_directory("static", filename)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

Place files in static/ folder.

Lesson 5: Request and Response

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask, request

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route("/echo", methods=["GET", "POST"])
def echo():
    if request.method == "POST":
        return f"You sent: {request.form['msg']}"
    return '''
    <form method="POST">
        <input name="msg">
        <input type="submit">
    </form>
    '''

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

Lesson 6: Forms and POST Requests

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask, request

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route("/form", methods=["GET", "POST"])
def form():
    if request.method == "POST":
        name = request.form["name"]
        return f"Hello {name}!"
    return '''
    <form method="POST">
        <input name="name">
        <input type="submit">
    </form>
    '''

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

Lesson 7: URL Parameters

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route("/hello/<username>")
def hello(username):
    return f"Hello {username}!"

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

Lesson 8: Redirects and Error Handling

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask, redirect, url_for, abort

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route("/")
def home():
    return redirect(url_for("about"))

@app.route("/about")
def about():
    return "About page"

@app.route("/error")
def error():
    abort(404)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

Lesson 9: Flask Debug Mode

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route("/")
def home():
    return "Debug mode example"

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

Lesson 10: Flask Blueprints

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask, Blueprint

bp = Blueprint("main", __name__)

@bp.route("/")
def home():
    return "Home from Blueprint"

app = Flask(__name__)
app.register_blueprint(bp)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

Lesson 11: Flask CORS

python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from flask import Flask
from flask_cors import CORS

app = Flask(__name__)
CORS(app)

@app.route("/")
def home():
    return {"message": "CORS enabled"}

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

(… and so on until Lesson 32 …)
